"Groove IP lite" allows you to make simple and clear (wi-fi) phone calls, tied to your Google gmail account, and the calls are totally free.  Microphones and speakers are built in to the unit, and the sound is clear and crisp.  There is an app called "Camera Launcher for Nexus 7" which allows you to take photos and videos with the 1.2 MP front facing pinhole camera.  While this tiny camera is primarily for use with Skype, the photos and videos captured with it are really quite good.  An app called "Kingsford Office" allows access (with editing, no less!) to Word, Excel, Powerpoint, and PDF documents either saved to the Nexus, or in your cloud storage. All four of these apps, as mentioned, are freebies.There is a fifth useful app (for sale at the Google Play Store for $2.99) called "Nexus Media Importer", which, in conjunction with a small USB OTG adapter, can display content from a USB thumb drive.  So who needs an SD memory slot?  The Nexus doesn't have to be "rooted" to utilize the adapter and app, and in theory, you can also attach peripherals, such as a mouse or keyboard, to the adapter.  In my opinion, all of these apps and the adapter should be part of the Nexus package.There are many native features of the Nexus that impress me, but two of them stand out.  The first is google search with voice, which I've tried, and is quite remarkable.  You can ask google search any search-type question in your own voice, and it answers instantly in a female voice which is very human-like, and it usually displays a diagram of the item asked about.  In a YouTube comparison test between Android's voice search and the iPad's Siri, Android won hands down.  And when it can't answer the question in voice, it displays the google search responses.  The second feature that impressed me is the "Type text by speaking" feature.  As you speak, it types what you speak on the screen.  And if you enunciate clearly, it does so accurately.  Of course, this technology has been available on PC's for years, and I even owned such a program, but it was very inaccurate.  To see it run accurately on a small tablet is very impressive.Bottom line:  This is an extremely remarkable and versatile little machine, with features and potential up the kazoo.  It is a sweet, sleek, and classy device, and like I said...almost perfect.

Reviews.Title: Love at first power up
Reviews.Author: J. W. Mullins
Reviews.Content: I've owned my Nexus for almost a year now. And even though I loved it the day I received it I wanted to wait before reviewing it so the 'new tablet smell' had worn off. As a comparison we also have a Kindle Fire HD and a Ipad 2 in our household. And while I'd prefer not to I don't think I can write a proper review without a little comparison to the other two.There are two major reasons I went with the Nexus instead of the Kindle or Ipad, price and Android. At the $200 mark the Nexus offers a lot of bang for the buck. It is thin, light, has good storage and a wonderful touch screen. And while I am not an Apple hater perse I despise Itunes since I use Window computers not MACs. I don't like the lack of control over my OS that I'd have to accept with the Ipad.Ease of moving files. When I want to watch, listen or read something on my Nexus I just plug it into a computer and drag the file onto the Nexus. No software required, no file conversions, no constant Itunes updates. As an example I watch a lot of .avi files on my Nexus and all that was required to do so was drag the file into the movie file folder. Then a quick download of MX player from the app store and I was good to go. I'd often had a headache converting media files on the Ipad and was amazed and thrilled by how easy it was to do on the Nexus. I've found that the Kindle Fire also offers a very simple process similar to the Nexus.Apps, so many apps. Apple has many times the apps as any other system and many are amazing quality. They have a QC process for apps to be added and thus more control that the Google store, that is undeniable. The top of the line games, apps and the like are often developed for the Ipad first and updated more often than for Android. That said I've been able to download free apps to watch every video, any music file, comics, books, and PDF files and had no issue with the Nexus. I do mostly use my tablet for social media and regular media with some web browsing. So the 'lack' of apps in the Google store is a none issue for me. It also means I have access to some fun games and apps that people have developed and don't want to go through the headache of getting approved through Apple. One thing I'd like to note is that while the Kindle App means you can download pretty much any book, you are limited when it comes to magazines/periodicals. Many are only available on the Kindle and if you are wanting to replace your paper magazines with digital versions the Kindle is the way to go.The touch screen on the Nexus is fantastic and I've never had an issue navigating screens or apps. That said there is just no way that the Nexus can compare to the Ipad at this price. The quality and the resolution are great, but with a side by side comparison the Ipad wins hands down. The Kindle Fire is very similar to the Nexus.Control. I love the level of control I have over the Android OS. I can essentially customize it however I want. When I plug my Nexus into my computer I have complete control. This doesn't make it complicated, as its easy enough to plug and play if you want to go that route. But it means for those who wish to you can customize everything from your home screen to your storage and settings. I don't like to pay money for something and then not be able to do what I wish with it. I hate even more to be locked out of software on a system that I own. A quick google search will show the vast amount of possibilities that are inherent with the open source Android system and the massive amount of support that Google offers for it.All and all the Nexus is my tablet choice hand down. While we have many tablets around the house the Nexus has become 'mine' and I use it far more than either the Kindle or Ipad. I do far more reading on it than expected. Couple with a set of Bluetooth headphones I also use it for my gym times instead of my Iphone. I can fit it in my pocket and the battery life means continental plane travel is a none issue for it. I recommend it without hesitation but you do need to really define what you want your table to do when you start shopping.

Reviews.Title: Great for the 48 hours it worked - Service and Quality Poor
Reviews.Author: Iowa06
Reviews.Content: Nexus 7 32GB worked great and I loved it for 4 days.  The product went completely dead, obtaining an RMA and shipping back the product which functionally was a piece of plastic with glass on the front was a long and time consuming process.  Received an RMA to return at my cost and 9 days later received a poorly packed Nexus 7 with a cracked screen.  After even more headache and time; as well as attempting to take clear photos of a cracked black reflective piece of glass I finally received an RMA number.  It took more than an hour on the phone before Asus decided they would consider replacing the defective unit that they sent back to me broken.  Back to Asus for the second time, my confidence in the product is falling and buyers remorse is sinking in.  They do send really sweet notes about how sorry they are for providing a non-functional product.  I prefer the clean Android operating system but at this point I would just like my money back or a certificate to the Apple store and we can just part ways.  I am surprised that Google puts their name on this product.

Reviews.Title: Best In It's Class
Reviews.Author: Danjel Bout
Reviews.Content: I have been a long time Ipad aficionado, despite my familiarity with Android systems.  I wanted to like the Android tablets, but they simply weren't a polished enough package.  The Nexus 7 changed my perceptions on the usability of an Android tablet, and they did so at a price well below the Ipad-Mini. What I wanted in a tablet was a robust platform to listen to audiobooks, read e-books in multiple formats, read through gmail, and use a few organizational applications. Could I do all of this on my Galaxy SIII? Absolutely, I would just run out of power half way through the day. The Nexus 7 is a great for these niche tasks, the screen can be easily read and the battery seems to last forever.  When you add to that the form factor - its so small I can tuck it in a large pocket and so light I can't tell its there - you have a winner in my book.  Did I mention the price? Buying the Nexus 7 was a no-brainer.

Reviews.Title: Bought The Old One on Sale!
Reviews.Author: Emissary52
Reviews.Content: I managed to snag the "old" Nexus 7 Wi-Fi 32GB model from Staples with a $30-off coupon last week, so the final price came out to $169 plus $11 and change for NC sales tax. I knew Google was coming out with the new, improved Nexus 7 and read about the upgrades that the new version would have. Since I'm not much of a gamer and already have the Kindle 8.9 32GB tablet, I figured that saving ~$100 over buying the new model suited me better. Plus Amazon is a super source for cases and screen protectors, which exist in quantity for the old Nexus as opposed to having to wait a few weeks for accessories to appear for the new version.As soon as I received the Nexus 7, I read online that Google had the Android Jellybean 4.3 for it on their developers' site ready to go. I downloaded it and found a program to install it, since I figured it would be a few weeks before Google rolled the update out over the air. My Nexus 7 came with Android 4.1.2 and when I went to upgrade it to 4.2.whatever, it said it was Up-To-Date. Yeah ...right! Well, I learned that upgrading most Android devices is a little more work than upgrading my original Kindle Fire, Kindle Touch and the Kindle 8.9 HD. Amazon has spoiled us Kindle people ...but I'm glad I learned the procedure to manually upgrade an Android device! That was a few intense hours well spent!I did manage to load a few apps on it - before I wiped it, when I did the upgrade, so I don't know how much better Jellybean 4.3 is, versus the older versions, but a few people have said it's made their old Nexus 7's a little perkier and the screen looks a bit more colorful. I also have a Lenovo A2107a 8GB and this Nexus 7 can run rings around it! It's like comparing a 10 year old Yugo to a new Corvette.My advice to potential Nexus 7 buyers - if you can get the old Nexus 7 32GB model for under $199 and you're not a gamer, but just need a general-purpose tablet ..then go for it! If you're a gamer, or just need to have "the latest and the greatest" get the 32GB new Nexus 7 and enjoy the 1080P screen and faster processor. All those people that bemoan both the new and old Nexus 7 not having an SD slot, just remember ...there isn't much other than music, photos and PDF's that you can put on it anyway! Most apps can't run correctly on those SD cards, which is why I always try to buy something with as much built-in memory as possible. To everyone who bought a Nexus 7, whether the old or new version ...enjoy your new toy!!!

Reviews.Title: The Next-Gen Tablet
Reviews.Author: T
Reviews.Content: I have owned the Nexus 7 32GB + 3G model for over two months now, and I have to say I'm quite impressed.  For a tech geek with 20+ years of computing behind me, there's always something missing in a product, this one came pretty close.  The N7 is an excellent product, both in hardware and performance.  The 7 inch form factor has a solid grip and the tablet is light enough to be handled by one hand.  The tablet is well built and sports a powerful processor and good enough RAM to get you going.Whether you're in for work, entertainment or web browsing it's powerful enough to handle it all.  The screen is high resolution and very clear.  I purchased an OTG cable and you can stick a flash drive and extend your capacity with full control over folders.  You can attach work documents, copy / paste files with ease.  The battery is over 8 hrs so it's good for all day computing.  It fits easily in most pockets.PROS+ Fast performance+ Sharp screen resolution+ 32 GB storage is good enough + you can use a flash pen+ Running the latest Android Jelly Bean 4.2.1+ Great battery life+ Wifi + 3G both work well+ Light & pocketable+ Lots of free stuff on the Play StoreCONS- No 4G / LTE- No HDMI support (can't imagine why)- No microSD card slot (no problem, just stick a flash drive)- Flash is not supported on the latest software (available if you root)- Nothing else reallyI've owned the iPad 2 Wifi model and it's a great tablet, but the N7 is more versatile and handy, and comes at a good price.4.5 / 5 stars

Reviews.Title: Loving it!
Reviews.Author: Donald Carlin
Reviews.Content: I was looking for a decent 7 inch tablet, to replace my iPad2 which was kind of commandered by my stepdaughter for her school. I looked at the iPad Mini, but could not justify paying nearly the same amount for a much smaller tablet so I decided to look into Android tablets. I first considered the Kindle Fire HD, but it seemed to have a more closed ecosystem for an Android tablet. So I looked at the Samsung Tab 2, I really liked the features, but having 3G data was important to me, because I used my old tablet for both media consumption and communicating. I looked over "no-name" brands, which looked good on paper, but most of the companies I never heard of and sinking $200 to $300 into a product without knowing the company did not appeal to me. Then I heard about the Google Nexus 7 and checked them out. The specs looked good to me; the graphics, the processor, the most current Android version, and Google just released a new model with 3G wireless data. And being pure Android, it had the open ecosystem Android is known for, unlike iOS and to a lesser extent the Kindle. I also had good experience with other Asus products so I took the plunge. I've been very happy with it. My first forray into Android has been very positive. I was able to find all my Chinese apps I used on my iPad and still use on my iPhone, and installed them on my Nexus, they work fine, in spite the Google Play message telling me they are not compatible with the Nexus 7 device. I really liked that I could work around that restriction, which would be much harder to do on iOS. The 3G works as expected, so I can stay in touch anywhere (provide it has coverage) And the battery life is very good. Over all, I am happy I took the chance and gave an Android platform a shot (but I still also like my iOS devices haha).Some issues which might bother some people and even be a deal breaker. There's no front camera, not much an issue for me, but I know others will insist on having one. No mini-SD slot, and I would have liked to have one on the Nexus 7, but still, on balance, the lack of SD was out-weighed by the other features in the end. Cellular data is only 3G, and I realize some people will want full 4G if they go with a cellular-enabled tablet. To me, it's one of those things that would be nice, but not a deal breaker, as I don't plan on streaming media from cellular networks.

Reviews.Title: Google Nexus 7 32GB HSPA+
Reviews.Author: Penny Gname
Reviews.Content: I bought mine in January directly from Google and it cost $299.I like it. I have been very resistant to getting into the mobile smartphone thing because I figured the small screen would just be frustrating, so when a fairly inexpensive tablet came along, I decided I'd give it a whirl. I can't compare it to an iPad because I've never owned one.It runs all the apps an Android phone will. There are quite a few articles and such with good recommendations for must-have apps. I was also interested in possibly using my tablet as a phone by using Voice over IP. Looks like that is possible. Using Google Voice and a couple of other apps.The one thing I didn't like was Google's customer support for this. They were just horrible, it was quite a nightmare.Oh yes, I also find the navigation/traffic isn't as good as what I have on my TomTom GPS. I thought I'd be replacing my TomTom with it, but I don't think I will.Pros:Price -- $299 from GoogleFunctionality -- Great!Voice recognition -- Works fairly well.Cons:Google customer support is horrid.On occasion it is a little laggy when responding to finger presses.I'm taking away one star for the terrible customer support service I received with an issue that should have been very easily resolved.

Reviews.Title: NO BUYERS REMORSE!
Reviews.Author: Robert York "maintain_composure"
Reviews.Content: A quick background: I own an iPad2, Blackberry Playbook, Surface RT, and Kindle Paperwhite. I bought the Nexus 7 32Gb with cellular 4G mainly because I own a Samsung Note 2 smartphone. The Nexus 7 was $299, without 4G it's $250.I am not going to compare it to any of the others except the iPad2 and iPad Mini. The Surface RT is not a valid comparison. The Surface RT is a productivity device with a full version of Office and a very cool keyboard/mouse combination. The keyboard snaps in and doubles as a cover. My daughter now uses it for school and loves it.If you own a regular size iPad, the Nexus 7 takes a few days to adjust to. The 7" form factor at first feels small for a tablet. However, once you start using it you begin to appreciate its portability and fantastic screen resolution. Now for the comparison to the iPad Mini.Pro's:1. Android 4.2 OS. It is the crem-de-la-crem (IMHO). I like it better than iOS.2. Quad core processor. For comparison, the iPad Mini is only a dual core.3. Screen resolution. The Nexus 7 is HD, the Mini is not the Retina (HD) display found on the regular sized iPad.4. Apps. Very much in line with Apple. I like some of the Android apps over Apple. For example, the Kindle app on Android is far superior to Apple. Apple does not allow you to purchase publication from the Kindle app... inexcusable.5. Google play for videos and music. It work really well.6. 1GB DRAM. The Mini only offers 500Mb. The Nexus 7 is a little speed demon!7. Batter life. 10 hours. Nice.8. Standard micro USB charging port. The Mini uses Apples proprietary charging port.9. Price! The iPad Mini, with far inferior specs, is $200 more than the Nexus 7.  If you get 4G, the Mini is $250 more than then Nexus!  That is difficult to justify.Con's:1. No rear facing camera. I NEVER take pictures or videos with a tablet so this is a worthless feature to me.2. No memory expansion slot. 32Gb provides plenty of space but a built in microSD slot would be nice. The Mini does not offer one either.3. No HDMI port. You can buy an add-on to hook into a TV if this is important. The Mini also does not offer a built-in HDMI port.That's it for now. I will update my review after using it for a month or two.

Reviews.Title: Rock Solid Device That Just Works!
Reviews.Author: D. Huynh
Reviews.Content: I like to think of myself as a tech savvy individual but when my family and I got together to celebrate my dad's big b-day this past January, I soon realize, I wasn't so.  You see, my older brother and sister both own new iphones, my niece and nephew both have ipad minis. And as of January, my dad now has the newest ipad 4.  While in contrast, I'm still rocking a 2007 Motorola Razr as my latest tech device.  Don't laugh, please.  Well, that's technically not true, I did purchase a new laptop last year, but it's nothing I would consider carrying around or deem to be portable.Well, after playing around with the ipad minis and ipad 4 during the get together, I realize how much I have been missing out. As mentioned earlier, I have a new laptop that I purchased last year which I love, but with a tablet, consuming media and information is so much easier and fun.  Was a tablet a necessary item to have?  For me, no, but's a great way to kill time and a heck of a lot of fun and in many respects has made my life easier.Well, shortly after, I made it my mission to get a tablet for myself.  I knew what I wanted - something in the 7-8 inch form factor.  My budget was set for $300 which left my options for mostly android tablets.  Also, I wanted to purchase my tablet at a brick and mortar store so that I can return the device in the event I had any issues.After doing some research, I settled on the nexus 7.  I decided on getting a nexus 7 because it was a Google device which meant it would get the latest os updates first.  Also, the device is stock android which means it does not have any added skins or modified OS (operating system), ie, samsung tab & amazon kindle, I'm talking to you.Display - 7 inch IPS screen with a resolution of 1280x800 and a 216 ppi (pixels per inch).  For me, the resolution is quite good.  Could it be better? Sure, but on a screen of this size, I think it is just more than fine.  Nice wide 178 degree viewing angles.  It's great, especially, when you need to show something off to a few friends.  The device has 350 nits of brightness so if you plan on using this outdoors in bright sunlight, it will be a struggle.  Keep this in mind.Battery Life- 4325 mAH (Google claims up to 8 hours of active use)  In my test of mix use: video playback, gaming, web browsing, emailing and e-book reading, etc - I can get about 7-7.5 hours with wifi on.  I have my screen brightness set at half way, I also have a live wallpaper and gps and wifi on, but bluetooth is turned off.  Your usage will vary depending on settings, of course.Appearance - The tablet has an understated look which I think is quite sexy.  There are only two physical buttons on the entire device which are located on the upper right hand side on the back of the tablet.  The button closest to the top is the power/sleep/wake button and sitting below it is the volume rocker. Once the device is powered on, you have 3 touch buttons which sit on the bottom center of the screen.  From left to right the buttons are as follows - back, home button and recent apps button. And the back of the tablet is constructed of a perforated rubberized non-slip material.Form Factor - I think a tablet in the 7-8 inch size range is nice size for carrying around when you are on the go.  I tend to wear cargo shorts mainly and my tablet fits nicely in all my front side pockets.  I'm not going to lie and say doing some things on this tablet is all that wonderful compared to a full size laptop, ie, browsing the web, for example.  On a device of this size it take a little getting use to but is very do-able once you get use to it.Performance - This tablet is sporting a 1.2 ghz processor with a Nvidia Tegra 3 cpu which helps to keep everything flowing nicely.  In addition, the latest OS - Jellybean with its project butter makes everything run smooth and effortless whether it's switching between apps, running graphic intense games, browsing the web or whatever your heart desires.  This little tablet can handle it.  Every app that I was able to download from the Google Play store just works.In summation, I really love this device and do not regret getting it one bit.  Yes, it is with its faults - no micro sd card slot, rear facing camera and no micro hdmi out but I knew that coming into it and those factors really didn't concern me all that much.  I was more concern about buying a solid device with decent hardware that could last at least a couple of years without being obsolete and also be reliable.  And I found that in this device.  If you do plan on purchasing this device or any device for that matter, I would recommend also purchasing a screen protector and a case for protection.  Thanks for reading and if this was in any way helpful, please fee free to give it a thumbs up.

Reviews.Title: Excellent tablet - workhorse
Reviews.Author: Lectrichead
Reviews.Content: So this year I decided to pick myself up an Android tablet at some point.  I needed to learn the `meats and potatoes' of Android, not just how to use it.  And I needed something hackable and customizable that I could both learn more about Android on as well as use in a practical manner.A Galaxy Tab was my first choice but the Nexus moved to the forefront after a bit.But it's only drawback was the lack of an SD slot. And I felt that this was a major drawback for sure.As these things goes, it happened that after the Nexus had been out for a while a simple dollar (or less) microUSB-to-USB (OTG) cable solved the lack of an SD slot problem.  With the Nexus Media Importer app, the cable, and whatever memory card reader or thumbdrive you want to plug into it - now it can have the ability to transfer data this way and overcome this limitation.This had been the thing holding me back from getting one, for the most part (as well as the money - I'm frugal), and while I had been prepared to buy a Nexus 7 after Xmas my wife beat me to it and picked up one for me, the 32GB one.So I have been using the Nexus for awhile while waiting for the cable to be shipped (which took taking quite some time as it's coming from China); well, I found that I really didn't miss it a bit.  With the various ways and apps for connecting to cloud storage, as well as using my own server, AND using the very excellent, very highly recommended (by me!) Airdroid app I don't miss not having an SD slot at all.Someday I know I'll really need to be able to transfer something via a thumbdrive or plug an SD reader into it - once I get the cable, but for now I don't miss it.  Likely two of the situations where I WILL need this kind of access might be while I am at a customer's and need to transfer something from a computer to the tablet (though I can do this with the Airdroid app anyway) or if I need to access some pictures off one of the sd cards from one of my cameras, like if I'm on vacation or something.I might even find myself taking a vacation or trip without my laptop.  <GASP>  (Sorry - I don't get this attitude of wanting to go technology-less on my vacation.  I'm not stressed out by technology, and I know when to turn it off, and I want to enjoy my vacation in every way possible.)It's possible now, as this Nexus comes close to many of the things I use my laptop for.  And as time goes on I find more useful and comparable apps that brings it closer to my laptop's abilities.  I think there's going to be a need for using my laptop sometimes, but I'm seeing less and less that I need the Vaio for the more I use this tablet.And as tablets become more powerful, and can access more devices (like keyboards and mice) the laptop will likely move more into the pervue of the desktop.  I see more and more people eschewing buying desktops and instead using laptops as their primary computer.A semi-side note here - the cable for plugging USB devices in came in the mail while I was in the process of writing this review.  Ecstatically I opened the package, plugged it in, and with the help of the USB app I was able to access thumbdrives, an SD reader, my Canon EOS Rebel and Canon A570 as well as my Canon digital camcorder directly with the Nexus.  No trouble, no fuss - no taking the memory cards out of the cameras, etc.  I also was able to plug a USB mouse into it and it works well.It's very easy to set up, and whether you like Google or not it's good to go through the process of setting up a Google account for syncing and backing up the tablet.As soon as you use it you can see right off the bat that the quad-core CPU and 12 core graphics chip pumps out a very smooth graphics experience, no matter what you are doing.  I will be able to show website demo's and photos and graphics to customers much easier than with my laptop.  Sure, smaller screen but easy to transfer stuff to their desktops for my serious perusal, with things like Airdroid.And it also has a "stealth" fifth core that takes over when there is less CPU demand and conserves power. I have noticed that if I'm just reading a book or doing something fairly passive with the WIFI and GPS turned off; it may show that I have two days worth of power.But it quickly drops when I do things like actively using the browser, typing with the keyboard, etc.  Still a pretty good battery life, not quite as great as the hype on the Google Nexus Page and I think it should be better.  Much better.  Or maybe it's just mine.  I have seen some suggestions that some are better at power conservation than others.I'd suggest it has a lot to do with what you have running.  It's so easy to allow EVERYTHING to give you notifications  but each of those things is checking the Wifi at intervals and using your power so considering turning notifications off on some stuff.  Usually you can just swipe the notification area down and touch the notification and access its options or menu to turn them off. The NFC allows you to "bump' or at least hold the device very near another device with the ability to transfer data.  I haven't actually tried it, and mine is inside a (cheapo) flip over case folio-style so I likely won't be giving this a shot.  But cool from what I have heard.WiFi reception seems to be real good, I live in an old house with 21 inch thick stone walls in one section, and more modern stick-built walls in the rest.  It seems to penetrate the stone quite well, though understandably at a lower signal strength.  But my other routers takes up the slack and pumps me back up to a good signal.  The Nexus switches seamlessly between the routers quite nicely, despite a slightly non-standard overlap of the router.It's a little awkward taking pictures of anything but yourself but it can be done and the pics are fine at 1.2 MP.  It would have been nice to have a rearward-facing camera.Using the tablet is a pleasure - it's fast and smooth as an iPad/iPhone/iPod and everything seems to work well.  Graphics and the screen are crisp, super-clear and clean.  So nice.  I won't go into speeds and such as I have yet to do any hardcore gaming - not really something I'm much into.Though, of course, so many apps want to leave you notifications, which slows your tablet and eats your battery, and of course for those who are a bit paranoid there are privacy issues when EVERYTHING pretty much can access your private data and location, etc.But a quick click on these notifications by swiping down the notifications section (top-right) and tapping them usually gets you somewhere where you can access a setting to turn off notifications.  This is one thing I don't like about the Android OS - the notifications are very pushy (pardon the pun).  But this is the fault of programmers, not the Nexus.I also keep the GPS and Bluetooth turned off unless I need to turn them on.  Like for mapping programs it's nice to have the GPS fired up, of course!I do occasionally have a crash and a time out in Google Play, but this is likely no the fault of the tablet and has more to do with our Virgin Mobile MiFi crapping out often - the only Internet we can get here (outside of dial-up).The Nexus' casing itself has a nice feel to it, the plastic has almost a leather or porous feel to it and is nicely non-slick (despite looking like it is).I won't go through all the installed apps and the stuff you normally would download, except to say it all functions nicely, smoothly, and many times seamlessly together.  If you want to use another app for defaults for various uses it's easy to set up, same as on any Android device.Widgets are nice, but I find that I don't really use them - it's nice to be able to see the weather at a glance but I'm going to click it any way for more info.  So I've kind of turned off the widgets I had tried out originally.  I like the screen space.Also love Jelly Bean's ability to make nice little IOS-like folders.  Excellent, easy (just drag n' drop), quick.Jelly Bean has some nice improvements over previous Android versions, like the task list and the swiping away of programs you don't want to run any longer.  I find I like Android more and more, and being based on LINUX (there's even going to be a mobile version of LINUX coming out sometime, from Ubuntu - but you can also try different flavors of LINUX right now n your Nexus if you like).The voice commands for Google Now work incredibly well.  With our home Dolby Surround Sound cranked it couldn't quite pick up everything I said, but that's pretty extreme - under normal circumstances it's amazingly accurate.  Ask Google a question and you'll probably get the answer.They keyboard is pretty standard, with predictive typing.  And I'm just getting into using Gesture Typing - swipe your finger over the letters you are typing without lifting your finger.  It seems incredibly fast, though takes some getting used to.  Lots of potential there.The screen itself is Corning® Fit Glass - which is not quite the same as Gorrilla Glass unfortunately, but it is very scratch resistant.I installed Flash on the Nexus 7, and it works well for me.  At least in my testing but a friend has told me that games don't seem to run correctly on it.  Which is too bad.There's some great apps out there.  And I find the tablet is very much becoming a replacement my laptop in some situations.

Reviews.Title: Added a star: It's a good value for what it is, well-priced, Android needs more and better-functioning apps
Reviews.Author: Random1040
Reviews.Content: I have the new 32GB version and started out with a mild case of buyer's remorse, but I'm warming up to it a bit more.[This was updated 11/24/2012. I'm adding a star to the review, after doing more research on other Android tablets, and updating a few other points, finding a few more uses, and reconsidering how the price fits.]First let me say that I looked at every option in existence [now a bunch more in person], and the Mrs. owns an iPad 3. We each also have laptops, and I own a ridiculously well-equipped desktop. At the end of the day, all of the current generation of tablets have shortcomings, and many have strong points. Of all of them, the Nexus 7 and regular iPad (3rd or 4th generation) are the best bets, though the Kindle Fire HD has a place. Let me just boil the review down easy here:The good:1) The N7 has a great build quality so far as I can tell. Everything from the shape to the textured rubber back makes sense. I don't hear any electronic noise listening to music with headphones.2) Jelly Bean [old and new version] run smoothly and are a clear improvement over past Android builds.3) The display looks really good. Not quite iPad3/ipad4/retina good, but close enough to not miss it during daily use.4) It's a great reader, and both Google's books and the Kindle app work like a charm. Google's app especially.5) Facebook, music, especially Google Play, also great. The stock email app, not so much.6) [NEW] As I student I use a flash card app which working nicely. Input info on a standard computer, and sign in on the N7. Any tablet can do this but extremely useful.7) The price is excellent, relative to what other tablet makers are offering. [Don't even bother with the iPad mini if it's on your possibilities list... if you're going to pay that you might as well just step up to the iPad 3 or 4 and enjoy the nice screen]The not terrible but could use work:1) Lack of apps. Don't underestimate this! I'd heard but didn't fully appreciate how bad it was. I had this dream of subscribing to my favorite magazines and newspapers and enjoying them in a nice format... not to be. The selection is pretty weak, though 3rd parties can aggregate them a bit even if they're a bit clunky. Another app I like on the iPad is Amplitube, which lets you simulate guitar pedals and amps as you plug your guitar into it (works well). No such animal on Android yet.2) Like most readers, it feels a little heavy. Or maybe not heavy, but a little awkward compared to a book. And my thumb always want to touch the spot that changes a page. Seasoned tablet people can probably ignore this, and in fairness the N7 is still better than most competing tablets I saw. Reading off a full size iPad3 is awkward as hell.3) A lot of missing features: no expandable storage, no HDMI are big ones. For the 32GB I wouldn't sweat storage unless you're a complete app pig and insist on keeping a huge media collection on the device (instead of one of the popular cloud services). HDMI I miss more, would be nice to be able to line out to a TV with some video content, but no dice.4) As with Apple, no Flash support. There are workarounds, but the two I tried didn't work out. I appreciate that Flash is dying (and it should), but there is still content out there that uses it.5) EDITED: Recharge not too bad. It was very slow using a different power adapter for whatever reason, the one it comes with does a decent job when run into the wall.6) Screen is a fingerprint magnet with a lot of glare. Plan on applying a film for that.7) The power & volume controls are a little too subdued the way they're placed. Minor point.All in all, it's a solid & well-built piece of work if you can use it. It's probably ideal for someone who uses public transportation and needs to pass the time with a device I'd call half reader, half toy. Provided you own a computer, TV and basic smartphone, this device will probably be redundant for you. If you're buying it to read bestsellers, read Tweets and fling some Angry Birds, [or study flash cards!] you'll be happy.Android' app ecosystem is the biggest concern here. And what they do have are often buggy or blown-up phone apps that are poorly optimized. There seems to be minimal development from publishers thus fewer magazines available. Tried out an app for Ms. Pac-Man, part of the screen is cut off. The Comcast/Xfinity remote control app is okay but gets stuck if you go to On-Demand. The 4.2 Update broke HBOGO (HBO's app that lets subscribers watch content). Just a ton of problems like that. Fair to say that's not this device's fault, but Android is part of the package.

Reviews.Title: Easy to Use but Get a Stylus for Typing
Reviews.Author: Carl Balduf
Reviews.Content: This is my first foray into tiny keyboards and was very frustrated with typing. I then acquired a capacitive stylus and all is now much better. In general, the screen is crisp and clean and the Jellybean 4.3 upgrade makes it much faster than my old desk top.  It connects easily to Wi-Fi and it's a lot of fun, though I can't see it doing much heavy-lifting computer-type work.  It's just fine for surfing the Internet, reading email and watching movies. I recommend it if the price is right.

Reviews.Title: Great product, great price.
Reviews.Author: Sunquark
Reviews.Content: This model does not have a rear camera but love the portability and power combination.  Used a lot for reading, browsing and music.

Reviews.Title: wont turn on, don't buy!
Reviews.Author: pawpaw1981
Reviews.Content: You can't love a tablet if it wont turn on. This product has issues with not taking a charge when the battery gets run down. The first time it happened we followed all this tricks, holding buttons while unplugging and plugging in the charger ect...and got it to work...tech support warned us never let it lose power completely it may NEVER charge again.  Well as life goes the wireless was left on while we were gone for a week end and yep, it lost all its charge and no tricks will work.  Tech answer, hope your warranty is still good.  Don't buy this tablet, I loved using it I really did, but it has a major flaw unfortunately.

Reviews.Title: Excellent product
Reviews.Author: emunozf
Reviews.Content: This tablet is very robust, easy to use, looks good, is comfortable and ideal for surfing the internet, watching movies, make presentations, read books, in short everything you could want, at low cost and with quality.

Reviews.Title: All it's cracked up to be and more
Reviews.Author: Janet L. Cannon "mrsjancan"
Reviews.Content: I've only had this baby a week and I can't believe how intuitive it is to learn to use. Although I have played with other tablets in the past, this is my first experience figuring out how one works without any instruction. The tapping interface is very accurate and very sensitive. I've tried it both with my finger and with a tablet pen. I do prefer the pen because I don't like smudge marks on the face of the tablet, but it's also a more accurate that way. ;-) I bought a case with a keyboard (and a converter cord so I could plug it in) but I'm not happy with the physical keyboard case and I seem to be able to type almost as fast on the touch interface. The only advantage is visual space (on the tablet, almost 1/2 your screen is covered when typing on the surface whereas typing on the keyboard you can still see the whole screen.) The only slight drawback is video playback is slow and has to buffer often, but part of that is my network, not the tablet. I didn't buy it for that reason, anyway. So if you want it for video, you probably need a 3G or 4G connection to really get a good video experience. Games, social networking, Google docs/calendar/cloud (anything with Google) work beautifully. Highly recommended.

Reviews.Title: Good then not good
Reviews.Author: David Smithers
Reviews.Content: It was 4-5  stars for the first 6 weeks. Then it stopped working, would not even turn on. I am obviously not happy now. Shipping it back for service so it is a 2 star now

Reviews.Title: 24 Hour Review
Reviews.Author: Jim Hart
Reviews.Content: This is a short review of the 32 gigabyte Wi-Fi Nexus 7.Asus Nexus 7 1B32 7-Inch 32 GB TabletSince this device is not new on the market and since there are literally thousands of reviews available this review comes from the perspective of the first 24 hours of ownership.  If you are looking for a long term usage review, or a review from experienced Nexus users you will have to search further.Background:My main purpose for acquiring the Nexus is to replace a Kindle Keyboard E-Book reader; the Kindle is a very nicely designed reader but does not offer color.  I wanted a device which would allow me to read technical manuals and follow color schematics, diagrams, etc.The obvious choice for a Kindle Keyboard replacement would have been the Kindle Fire HD, except that nearly everything I read noted that the operating system on the Fire (Android) has been customized to make the device the best Kindle it can be.  For the same price the Nexus 7 offered Android in a more open configuration, thus allowing more choices when customizing the device.I chose the 32 gigabyte model over the 16 gigabyte model because (a) the extra storage was "only" a 25% increase over the cost of the base model and (b) I was (and still am) not quite certain what I will end up storing locally on the device and wanted to maximize my option.I did not purchase the Nexus from Amazon, I purchased it at a local computer store because I wanted a "hands on" look at the device before purchasing.Setup:I found the original setup (not to be confused with customizing) the Nexus very simple.  I had my wireless router set to broadcast the SSID (the name of the network), and the Nexus located the network without issue and logged in when I supplied the network key.A Google account is required; I already had a Google account and the device had no problem logging into that account once I supplied the necessary username/password.Customization:E-Reader:I downloaded and installed the Kindle app, which registered the Nexus in my Amazon Kindle account.  At that point all of the books which are in my Kindle library became available on the Nexus.  They did not automatically download, rather they are shown within the Kindle app as "archived".  The archive is searchable and clicking on a book then downloads the book into the local storage of the Nexus.  Of course one must have a Wi-Fi connection in order to download books, given that this review is on the Wi-Fi model of the Nexus.The screen of the Nexus, unlike the Kindle Keyboard, is back lit. I have had no issues with eye fatigue, etc. reading books on the Nexus (and I gave it a pretty good run through, since for me this is the "killer app" of the device; if the e-reader had not worked well the device would have been returned).One caveat - the Kindle Keyboard is lighter, and has controls for paging up/down on each side of the device - thus making it easy to read one handed with either hand.  The Nexus 7, having a touch screen, requires that the page be turned by swiping one's finger across the screen, from right to left to move forward and left to right to move backward.  This makes reading one handed problematical.The Kindle Keyboard has excellent characteristics for reading outside in the sunlight; I have not yet tested the Nexus 7 for reading outside because that would not be a deal breaker for me.  I rarely read outside in the sunlight.It should also be noted that books on the Keyboard Kindle can be organized into "Collections" for easy organization.  That feature is not available on the Nexus (nor on the Kindle Fire HD, as far as I am aware).Email:After confirming that the Kindle app would work well enough to replace the Kindle Keyboard I set up Hotmail.  Although I have a Google account my primary email account is through Hotmail; I use Outlook 2010 on my computers and sync contacts, calendar, and email through Hotmail.  I wanted to have the Nexus sync to that data as well.  Following the on screen instructions after clicking on the E-Mail icon setting up Hotmail was a breeze.  I did not have to manually configure the ports or other settings, the Nexus automatically handled the setup once the username/password was supplied.I've confirmed that making changes on the Nexus syncs to Hotmail, and thus back to Outlook on my computers.  Note that 'contacts' data is shown under the "People" icon on the Nexus; modifying or deleting a contact in "People" syncs back to 'contacts' in Hotmail.  Calendar and mail, of course, sync as well.Anti-Virus:I installed the AVG Anti-virus from the Google Play Store.  I have some experience with AVG (I am a retired I.T. technician) and their freeware version installed easily, performed a scan quickly, and there are not any overly onerous screen ads.Printing:I installed Google Cloud Print on one of my home computers and following the prompts registered all of my home printers (I have a home network comprised of several computers and printers).  I then installed the Cloud Print app from the Play Store on the Nexus, following the prompts, and sent test prints to an HP LaserJet printer.  Printing was very quick.  Note that Cloud Print allows one to print documents but there is, as far as I have been able to determine, no "Print" directly available from E-Mail.  However this is, after all, a "24 hour" review and I have not extensively investigated the possibilities of Cloud Print.Edit: 2/14/13 - I found that the computer upon which Cloud Print is installed needs to have the printer "owner" logged in; otherwise the HP LaserJet did not print, the job was held in the queue, even though the computer was powered up.  The printer is networked, not connected directly to the computer; the problem seems to be the way Google Cloud Print accesses the IP of the printer.  I resolved this situation by making a Kodak Hero 7.1 ink jet printer the default, and setting up "Cloud Ready" printing.  The Kodak software coordinates with Google to give a direct path to the printer, removing any computers from the mix.  I confirmed by turning off all of the computers from my home network and sending a print job to the Kodak from the Nexus; the job printed almost immediately.  I recommended that if one is looking to print from the Nexus on a regular basis that a "Cloud Ready" printer (there are many) be used if possible.  Brother Corp has a printer:http://www.amazon.com/Brother-HL-2270DW-Compact-Wireless-Networking/dp/B00450DVDY/ref=wl_it_dp_o_pC_nS_nC?ie=UTF8&colid;=70H9A6UDQYQN&coliid;=I266I6ACMF5T49that comes with it's own version of such printing, but I do not own that printer and so cannot verify that it will print from the Nexus independent of computers.Microsoft Office:Office 2010 is installed on all of my computers and is my 'go to' resource for documents.  Obviously Office isn't going to install on the Nexus. I installed Kingsoft Office, a free app from the Play Store, and tested by opening an email attachment which was in Word format. There were no issues, with the caveat that Kingsoft generated a message that there was no suitable File Explorer installed on the Nexus.Edit: 2/3/13 - After installing Google Cloud Drive on my laptop I created an Excel file and saved it to Google.  I opened the file on the Nexus using the Kingsoft Office, edited, and uploaded it back to Google.  When opened on my laptop the changes were in place.  If you need more details on the Kingsoft Office capabilities I would recommend "Googling" the software and reading the reviews.  I do not expect to be creating complex documents or spreadsheets on the Nexus, but it is heartening to know that there is some level of document sharing/editing/creating available.File Explorer:Following the message from Kingsoft Office I installed the app ES File Explorer, a freeware app from the Google Play Store.  It installed easily and works with Kingsoft.Google Plus:I set up Google Plus but have not investigated the application.  One can only do so much in 24 hours :-) .Games:I am not a huge gamer; I installed Hearts from the Google Play Store and tested. It works similarly to the Hearts game installed on Windows 7.  Screen rendering of the cards is excellent.Maps:I set up Google Maps, allowing the device to find my current location.  Screen resolution is excellent.  I have not yet used the Maps/GPS other than to install the app.Movies:"Ice Age" came licensed on the device; I spent a few minutes watching the movie and the screen rendering is excellent.  The sound is acceptable - but note that "acceptable" is totally subjective.  The speakers are on the back side of the Nexus, which is not optimal.Overall:I am well pleased with the Nexus after a day of setup and usage.  While it is obviously not a laptop or even a netbook I think that the device does have possibilities for not just the consumption of content but also the creation of content.  The screen is excellent, the range of apps (while not equal to the number of iPad apps) is extensive and growing, the processor is quick to respond and the price point competitive.

Reviews.Title: beware of screen flicker problem
Reviews.Author: D. Zarder "dzarder"
Reviews.Content: I had been very excited to receive my google nexus 7 android tablet.  Almost everything about it was great.  Android jellybean turned out to be very nice and the tablet's performance was very fast.  But, while reading epub books, I noticed a problem with screen flicker.  I didn't know anything about this flicker problem when I first made the purchase.  But, as soon as I noticed it, I found a lot of info on varoius websites from other customers who had experienced the same thing.  The flicker problem is most noticable when reading epub books.  After every page turn, there is a slight strobe-like flicker that repeats 3 or 4 times.  After that the screen seems OK until I turn to the next page and the same flicker occurs again.  Turning off the auto-brightness feature, as some had suggested, did not resolve the problem.  Maybe it doesn't sound like a major deal to you, but it soon becamse very annoying, since I bought the table mostly for reading.  I ended up returning the tablet and am now considering other options.

Reviews.Title: Very Happy
Reviews.Author: D. Jones
Reviews.Content: I have owned a kindle fire and nook and I must say that this is the best out of the tablets that I have had experience with. #1 its very fast! The quad processor really loads fast. #2 the play store is still the best store with better apps and a lot of vs the other tablets. #3 the price was $200 for the 16 GB which was pretty good as well. I'm also impressed with the screen quality and the SOUND. I use the Dr. Dre headphones and it sounds as if it has the "beats" technology built in. Overall I'm very happy with my tablet. I would have given it 5 stars but there is no option to have memory expansion(USB, sd cards etc.) Other than that I love the nexus 7!

Reviews.Title: Defective
Reviews.Author: Eruntalon
Reviews.Content: It took me a long time to decide to purchase another tablet.  I have or have had an iPad, a HP Slate (work made me), and a Motorola Xoom, all of which worked fine for their intended purpose.  I wanted a new and smaller one for home, mostly for reading (books, web, and docs).  I took a long time deciding between the Kindle Fire and the Google Nexus 7 and ultimately decided on the Nexus because it was not as locked down as the Fire.I received the item today and it was a beauty right out of the box and the setup was simple.  I let it charge and went about my day.  Finally sat down to try it and within 5 minutes the touch sensor started going crazy.  Simply touching the side or even just tilting it would activate all areas at once, resulting in random selections being made.  I tried removing the case and it still malfunctioned.  I removed the screen protector and it still malfunctioned.  Gave up, filled out the RMA and sat down to write my first review on Amazon.

Reviews.Title: My first tablet experience and really love it.
Reviews.Author: mavile76 "mavile76"
Reviews.Content: Did my research. Was thinking about a mini at first but then this option came. Did my research. Saw some comparisson videos on YouTube and CNET, and simply found that both fit my needs can get the same accomplished but the nexus 7 has a much better price and more storage 32gb.  Google cloud services really help me get the most out of my 32gb. Really love the size. 7' is much more comfortable to hold and convenient and fits right in your pant pockets.  Oh and did I mention android jellybean is great? Had android on smart phones and got hooked on androidb since. Jellybean only makes the experience better.

Reviews.Title: The Best "Budget" Tablet on the Market (From a Former Kindle Fire Owner)!
Reviews.Author: Kevin Currie-Knight
Reviews.Content: Up until this past week, I owned a Kindle Fire HD (which I got refunded because of a hardware hiccup). I bought a Nexus 7 instead and, while I liked my Fire, I prefer the Nexus 7 in ALMOST every way. Below are some comparisons I've made between the two devices. Which one you end up with largely depends on what you want the device for, but here are some considerations.Android versus Kind-of-Android: As my Fire review attests, I took to Amazon's heavily 'skinned' Android more than I thought I would. But with the Nexus 7, you get Android Jellybean in all of its fullness. The Kindle Fire is the easier to navigate device, as the homescreen is basically a carousel of recent items and a list of categories (apps, books, games, movies, web) that you can select. But the Nexus 7's Android is fully customizable with the traditional five home screens you can use to place apps, widgets, bookmarks, and the like. Full Android takes some learning (ICS is more intuitive than prior releases, though), but if you want customization, Nexus beats Fire. I should also mention the internet browsers. With the Kindles, you get Amazon Silk, a fairly slow browser (yes, it markets as fast, but it is slow by every measure) whose biggest selling point is text-rendering. With Nexus, the default browser is Chrome, but there are some other great tablet-optimized browswers like Puffin and Dolphin; while none of them have text-rendering like Silk, a few are flash-enabled, allow private browsing, and some other stuff that Silk does not allow.Reading, Listening, and Watching: I use my tablet largely as a media consumption device, and toward that end, Amazon is second to none. Those of us locked into Amazon's ecosystem of books, movies, and music will do well with the Fire and its integration into the Amazon universe. Buy a book or album, it shows up on your device (or your cloud). Have Prime? It is easy to stream Prime videos straight to your device. But here's the thing: you can do a lot of this (except for streaming video) on the Nexus, as Amazon's apps are freely available on the Play market. The two things you will (kind of) give up are the robustness of the kindle ebook reading experience (text-to-speech, for instance, is only available on kindle devices) and streaming Prime movies. Of course, I said "kind-of" give up because you CAN stream prime movies on the Nexus 7 via a few Flash enabled browsers that you can find by doing a web search. Oh, and as far as ereading apps, you are not locked into any one provider on the Nexus: Google Boooks, Nook, Sony Reader, Mantano Reader, Aldiko - it is all easily available on the Play market (where with the Fire, you have to go through a fairly tedious sideload process).Tablet Hardware: Okay, here, the Nexus 7 is the CLEAR winner. In honesty, the Fire and Fire HD just strike me as somewhat cheaply made (and the Fire is just bulky). The Nexus is not only an inexpensive tablet, but a really pretty and solid-feeling one as well. It is lighter than the Fire (by a lot) and HD (by a noticeable little). The screen is just better on the Nexus than the HD (even though the specs are roughly the same), and the Nexus is DEFINITELY faster than either the Fire or HD. The two areas where I think the Kindle does have the advantage hardware-wise are that the side bezels are thicker (more room for your thumb to grip the front of the device in portrait mode), and the speakers (Fire and HD have stereo speakers that are very good quality, while Nexus has one speaker that is light and tinny).What each has that the other doesn't: The Nexus is more of a serious tablet than the Fire. It has features like Google voice search (like Appple's Siri, but more polished), Google Now (sort of a personal planner), and GPS. None of these are available on the Kindle Fire.On the other hand, the Fire and HD are great media consumption devices: on the devices, you get text-to-speech for most kindle books, whyspersync (where you can buy the book and audio book combo and have the kindle sync them so that you can switch between the two), and streaming of Prime video (per above, a big awkward on the Nexus). While not particularly a feature of the Fire or HD, I should mention that Amazon has phenomenal customer service for these devices, while Nexus customer support is spotty.Really, it comes down to what you want. As you can see, both devices have features the other does not have, but for my money, I still prefer the Nexus on balance. It is a more solid tablet (remember, my Fire HD's hardware encountered problems, which isn't normal, but it isn't abnormal). And it is a tablet that, unlike the Fire and HD, do not seek to lock you into one content provider. If it is available on the Play market, I can get it. And the Nexus's Google Voice and Google Now features are surprisingly helpful.

Reviews.Title: Good stellar product from Asus/Google
Reviews.Author: JDeltree
Reviews.Content: Being my 2nd tablet and 2nd tablet from Asus as well. I must say that the Nexus 7 is a perfectly crafted device. It feels well built and tightly put together. When compared to my asus transformer prime which was more of a fragile shiny 'statement' tablet, the Nexus 7 still stands out tall. 7 inches seems perfect for a tablet. I doubt i would ever be going back to 10 inches. The comfortable build you get as well as stock android jelly bean makes this tablet an addictive piece of tech. I have not been able to put this down since I received it. This is a 3G model as advertised and everything came sealed and neatly packaged (as expected) in 2days after I placed my order. Note however that this does not come with the capability to text or make phone calls out of the box. There are some 3rd party apps for text messaging as well as other options which would require root access. As for phone calls, I am yet to find any suitable means of getting regular network gsm calls to work. The apps you find only help you make voip calls - a solution i'm not interested in. Its not a deal breaker for me anyway. I doubt I really want to be making calls or texting....I basically needed 3G functionality for connectivity while on the go.I would definitely recommend this tablet as well as the services of the seller.

Reviews.Title: My favorite tablet thus far
Reviews.Author: Hsghori
Reviews.Content: Okay let me start off by saying that I did not buy my Nexus 7 from Amazon. I recieved it as a gift, but after a month of use I felt that I needed to tell others about it.I have played with an ipad, a samsung galaxy tab, and a kindle fire so I know my tablets pretty well.I use my Nexus to play games, stream videos, surf the web, and take notes during class, and these are some observations that I have made.PROSHardware- The Nexus 7 boasts extremely impressive hardware including a 1.2 gHz processor, 1gb of ram, and (in this case) 32gb of storage space.Android OS- The Jelly Bean Android OS is amazing, smooth, and works well with the 7in tablet design. For me switching from iOS to Jelly Bean felt like taking the training wheels off of my bicycle. At first I felt overwhelmed but after a day I was able to figure out the OS and am now able to operate it with ease. Jelly Bean is extraordinarily customization since you can find several different customization apps on the Google Play store.Google Play- Apple boasts that it has the largest selection of mobile applications in the world. While this may be true, the Google Play store also has a large selection of apps that allow you to do anything from playing games to streaming TV shows and movies. All of the more popular apps (angry birds, facebook, netflix, hulu, skype, etc) are there.Size and build- The 7in size of the Nexus 7 is perfect for the person who is on the go often. You can easily slip it into a purse or a bag, even with a case, and you can hold it easily with one hand even if you have smaller hands. People tend to complain about the "rubber" back of the tablet but I happen to like it. It doesn't slip when its on a desk or table and feels nice and solid in your hands.Battery Life- My nexus can last a couple of days of use even with light video watching. Sometimes I can get through an entire day while only using 20% of the battery (though usually this sould be a day of pretty light use).CONSLagging- Sometimes the tablet will lag quite significantly. A quick restart fixes the problem thoughThickness- Not a problem for me, but some people prefer a thinner tablet. The Nexus is a little thick, especially compared to an iPad.No rear camera- Personally I never plan to take pictures with my tablet when I have a nice phone handy. However it is good to know that the Nexus does not have a rear camera. It does have a front-facing camera that can be used for video chatting.CONCLUSIONIt you are looking for a 7in tablet that will last you a while, look no further. I would definitely recommend that you buy the Nexus 7.

Reviews.Title: Trend Setter and Game Changer
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I like all those things which has proved the greatest Steve Jobs wrong or even has potential of doing it. Because such things has to be something beyond the greatest. Examples: (i) Software and hardware has to go together: Windows and PC proved it wrong. Then again Android proved it wrong. (ii) Touch devices with stylus dead on arrival: Galaxy Note proved it wrong. (iii) Who reads books? First Kindle proved him wrong. (iv) Tablet of smaller than 10 or 9 inch screens are of no use.AND THEN COMES NEXUS 7 TO PROVE HIM WRONG AGAIN.IN SHORT ITS GAME CHANGER OR TREND SETTER, AFTER THIS DEVICE, SMALLER SIZED TABLETS MIGHT BECOME FASHION AND GO HEAD TO HEAD OR EVEN FAR THAN THEIR BIGGER BROTHERS.MARK MY WORD : YOU WILL USE LESSER BIGGER SIZED TABLETS OR LAPTOP FOR THAT MATTER ONCE YOU HAVE IT.IT'S ALWAYS MORE FUN TO PLAY WITH YOUNGER ONES RATHER.Now please proceed to the detailed review of this great device (this deserve it)1. VERY BEAUTIFUL DEVICE: SIMPLE, SLEEK, SEXY AND LIGHTWEIGHT. ITS LIKE APPLE DEVICE MINUS ALUMINUM IN BACK FOR HALF OF THE MONEY.2. MOST PORTABLE AND CONVENIENT TO USE AND CARRY. BEST FOR CASUAL USAGE: Its just like novel which you can put in pocket and use it any convenient position. Nothing beats it in this regard. People are using it even for serious work.3. VERY POWERFUL.4. VERY SMOOTH AND POLISHED OPERATING SYSTEM equivalent to iOS but more powerful, flexible and customizable. It puts YOU IN COMMAND and don't let you feel helpless or dumb. You can do the things when you have the need for it.5. VERY GOOD SCREEN resolution (216 PPI). Viewable from all angles.6. STOCK ANDROID: BELIEVE ME NOTHING COMPARES TO STOCK ANDROID EXPERIENCE. With other variations you will most likely be outdated for some duration at least and that too with inferior UI.7. COMPARED TO KINDLE DEVICES: ITS BETTER than those as you can have amazon ecosystem on this but not vice-versa. Kindle ecosystem is very limiting.8. PRETTY DECENT SPEAKERS for its size.9. Very well integrated with Google ecosystem.10. GOOGLE ECOSYSTEM IS MORE CONSUMER FRINEDLY IN GENERAL, they have more free, FEATURE RICH applications (almost double). They have recently offered many popular applications free or just for a quarter. I have bought one application @25 cents which otherwise comes for almost 14 dollars. Unlike Apple, Google is not making any money on the hardware as they want to earn on its usage. Remember Apple steals your hard earned money first on hardware then on 'limited' usage too.11. Make no mistake its BEST VALUE FOR THE MONEY: If Apple replaces its plastic back with Aluminum IT WILL BECOME AN APPLE DEVICE and they will charge gold for an aluminum. And mind you plastic here is better here for its does not feel slippery.12. FRONT CAMERA: NO COMPLAINT for what it is made for.It could be better in the following areas:1. Expandable SD (Workaround : by OTG cable in less than dollar and use it with nexus media importer for $2.49 [workks without rooting]) AND PRACTICALLY YOU CAN UNLIMITED STOARGE ON YOUR DISPOSABLE and you can swich/detach/exchange on your will.2. No Flash: This fault is not of Android/Google as Adobe itself is not supporting Flash anymore. (Workaround: Free Puffin web browser [works without rooting])3. No HDMI (Buy any micro USB to HDMI adaptor). I personally don't feel need for it though.4. No Cellular connectivity: Not a big deal as 8 out of 10 tablets sell just with wifi. And you are saving money on hardware and data plan. I tether with my unlocked nexus phone without paying a single penny.5. Speaker sound is little muffled on high volume (use any free EQ application).6. Back Camera: I don't care as I don't want to steer tablet to take photos I want to shoot photos.GOLDEN WORDS IN END: ITS BEST MONEY FOR THE VALUE AND GAME CHANGER DEVICE, GO FOR IT.TIP: BUY IT FROM STAPLES/OFFICE DEPOT/SEARS/WALMART. Seems they have much lesser complaints about quality. We three friends bought this and we are much more than satisfied. Its one of our best purchase so far.

Reviews.Title: Great value on a nice tablet with slightly outdated processor...automatically upgrades to Kit Kat 4.4.2.
Reviews.Author: V. Lockwood
Reviews.Content: The main points that led me to purchase this tablet were:1. Price2. The amount of memory3. The fact that it is a Nexus 7 means that my operating system will always be up to date.Within minutes of turning the device on and connecting to the internet, it was already starting to update the OS. It was all automatic, all I had to do was watch while it rebooted a couple of times. First it updated to the highest version of Jelly Bean, then it rebooted and updated to KitKat 4.4.2. I was concerned that there might be a performance hit, but I am not noticing anything like that at all. I read that some users have had problems updating this Nexus 7 2012 up to KitKat. They experienced a slow down in the operation of the tablet. Perhaps they should have done a factory reset before the upgrade. The slowdown problem that I read about seemed to have to do with a cache that was left on the system at the time of the upgrade. A factory reset would have deleted that, as well as any other legacy files.Because of all of the security issues with outdated operating systems and software that have been happening lately, I came to the decision that I will no longer buy devices that will be left hanging without official OS updates. Windows and Apple both manage to do this for a reasonable amount of time after purchase.  So why can't Google force the device makers to do this, at least for the first few years of ownership?  Until this happens I will not buy Android phones or tablets that are not supported by Google. Phone and tablet makers who are not willing to help extend the life of our devices and keep our data as secure as possible by giving us the latest operating systems should not be supported in my opinion.This tablet is on sale at Best Buy this week for $149, saving ~$100 over what the 2013 Nexis 7 with 32 GB would have cost me.  There will come a day when it will start to feel sluggish, when that happens it will be time for a new tablet. But this one, because it has 32 gigabytes of storage built in, will always be viable as a GPS, music player or for photo slideshows.

Reviews.Title: my nexus google tablet
Reviews.Author: grams angels
Reviews.Content: I love this product only thing wrong is that it has no camera, I was hoping it had a good camera on it. but other than that I love it.

Reviews.Title: The best tablet at  $150
Reviews.Author: Souvik Pal
Reviews.Content: Bought this as a gift for my parents. What can I say about Nexus except that it is great! I don't have to re-certify the fact that its clearly one of the all time best 7" best tablet ever sold. I have a iPad2 and in terms of silky smooth touch response, iPad is still may be a few points ahead than nexus, but my iPad2 cost me well in excess of $500 versus the nexus at $150, which raises the question is iPad really worth that much extra cash? This is the 2012 version, and the 2013 nexus is even better what I have heard. My iPad2 is showing signs of aging, so I will probably buy 2013 version as well. If you are looking for a 7" tablet, this is the must have tablet. Believe me,  the other 7" tabs are not worth the extra cash. I know in 10" tab genre, Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 and iPad air are the major players, but nexus beats everyone else in 7" form factor tablet market.The only major drawback with this one is that USB on the go is not enabled by default. You have to root it which may not be trivial for normal people.

Reviews.Title: A really great buy for an engineering student!
Reviews.Author: Micky
Reviews.Content: Freaking awesome, I'm an aerospace engineering student & this actually meets almost all of my needs. It runs MATLAB, Catia, and AutoCAD beautifully, as well as all Citric based programs that my school offers through the wireless drives. The camera's pretty crappy, but I don't think you're looking at this for use as your primary camera...it also runs normal apps (fb, pinterest, weather, FML, cut the rope, etsy, spotify, etc.) perfectly. It has some trouble with Surfline...idk why. Also, the Bluetooth range is not very far, maybe about 15ft max. I can take my speakers at least twice as far from my iPhone before I start to have problems. Overall though, this is a great product. Its very light, I can put it in my school bag, and I am never dissapointed with it.

Reviews.Title: Happy
Reviews.Author: Janell Penha "Jay. Pen"
Reviews.Content: I am glad I bought this. This was a special gift and we both enjoy using this. I selected a good product.

Reviews.Title: Good product Nexus!
Reviews.Author: HIT THOSE SMALL KEYS
Reviews.Content: Fine little tablet. Most pleased.I highly recommend it. Met all my expectations hence have given it as presents to other family members,

Reviews.Title: Exactly what I needed
Reviews.Author: Keith Latham
Reviews.Content: I was tired of lugging around my laptop while traveling: Pulling it out for TSA, bringing a whole bag to a coffee shop, and ultimately adding 5lbs and bulkiness to my bag. Sure a laptop can do more, but I wanted this for browsing the web, watching movies, listening to music, and playing games: Entertainment. It does just that with a battery that lasts 8x what my laptop is capable of.Pros:-Customize the looks, the layout, the options are endless-Long battery life-Can be rooted to use flash drives (I recommend if you know what you are doing because we can't always depend of wifi)-The price beats almost all competitorsCons:-After 2 weeks, I still can't find any.I recommend getting a bluetooth keyboard with it and you have a new travel buddy.

Reviews.Title: Great tablet!
Reviews.Author: Wenceslao Martinez "Beach comber"
Reviews.Content: Smart, compact and easy to use! Fast to connect via Wi-fi. Brilliant colors in its screen make using it a pleasure.

Reviews.Title: I really like my Tablet
Reviews.Author: Mezchelyn Ellis
Reviews.Content: I purchased two other tablets and they barely worked, a co-worker recommended Asus, despite my low expectations, thinking I would have to buy the ipad, I was releaved to find how excellent this tablet worked.

Reviews.Title: You can't go wrong.
Reviews.Author: Sarnian
Reviews.Content: Wow. This is an amazing tablet that still fits in my pocket. I had used a Playbook before and there is simply no comparison. What I like best is the seamless integration of all my Google apps across all my devices. No need for me to do anything it just happens! A fantastic tablet at a ridiculously low price.

Reviews.Title: Without a magnetic case, a fine tablet that works
Reviews.Author: Dustin F. Hecker "Ideological not partisan"
Reviews.Content: I have been using the original Nexus since July 2012. I am on my second one. With both, the screen simply would go black, repeatedly, in the middle of reading about anything.  I then needed to close the cover, push the power button and/or store the screen, generally a number of times, to resurrect what I was trying to read. I have tried everything that Google's very responsive support personnel suggest, including doing factory resets.  Nothing worked, and I was prepared to review (and had originally reviewed) the tablet as one not to buy.However, I then found a forum thread that explained the problem can be caused by magnetic cases, which are useful to keep the case closed and to automatically darken the screen when the case is closed.  As my "Dodo" case was about to fall off anyway, I have been trying the tablet without any case.  Voila!  The problem appears to have disappeared.With that resolved (Google support -- please note), the Nexus 7 is a fine tablet.  Good screen, quick navigation, good third-party apps, fair price.  Quality feel and a good size (large enough screen and it fits in my pocket if need be).

Reviews.Title: Nexus 7 sucks
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I bought this device in November 2013. Initially it worked well however by February 2014 it just went dead ....wasn't recharging or turning on. I was very disappointed when I contacted Amazon to be told that the time for returning/replacing had expired. This is madness. What about my expectation that the device would work for a reasonable time. The point is that I don't know what the problem is...battery?  screen?. This has been my worst purchase experience

Reviews.Title: a must have for Linux fans
Reviews.Author: Kaitlynrenee
Reviews.Content: First off let me say, this tablet is made for modding.  The 2013 edition is lacking quite a bit in that area.  I'm sure it will also have more rooms available in time, but for now, this is the one to buy.  If you do not care about custom roms then there is no point in reading further.  Thanks to ingenious modders, the 2012 version of this tablet is capable of running Ubuntu desktop 13.04.  With an mhl adapter, you can make any hd tv with an hdmi port your monitor.  This truly is a mobile desktop computer that fits into your purse or pocket.  If you're a fan of Linux operating systems and want functionality offered by very few tablets, then this is the tablet for you.

Reviews.Title: Months later I am still amazed at this little device. Everyone should own one!
Reviews.Author: Michael Laferriere
Reviews.Content: I originally started looking around at getting a tablet after seeing how useful they are for astronomy after seeing what the Celestron Skyscout could do. Think about it, you can download an app such as Google skymap, Skyeye etc. and hold the tablet up against the sky and it will show you what stars, planets, nebula's are behind it. Everyone into astronomy should know the basics but its nice to be able to quickly verify what you are looking at. These are a little harder to attach to a scope but if you are into astrophotography you likely want to keep your scope as light as possible unless you have a pier mounted Astrophysics mount or similar. But for a larger Dobsonian you might be able to attach it directly to the tube and use it as a crude spotter or for push-to guiding.I researched iPads at first since they seem to be the most common and reliable but was not happy with how quickly Apple obsoletes its older products. I used some astronomy software on an iTouch but Apple won't allow updates to download to it since it is an older version. A fellow astronomer on Astronomyforum.net suggested I try a Nexus tablet over a cheaper droid device. I'm really glad I listened as really feels nice in the hands, durable and quick as it needs to be. The 32GB is ample to load up several DVD quality movies and the Wifi moves these back and forth in minutes.Unfortunately instead of using this for AP I wound up getting distracted with the great variety of tasks it can accomplish. It is really nice being able to take this out for a quick visit to a news site, Panoramio, Foursquare, Google, Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn etc. Its like having a fully functional computer that you can jam into a fat pocket!My biggest use so far has been loading it up with movies or TV shows to watch since I have a long commute for work. The portability of the Nexus 7 beats any portable DVD or Blue-ray player and the battery lasts longer than that I have owned. Its also nice being able to load up several movies and not have to swap discs. The device is also fully capable of streaming Youtube, Hulu etc when in WiFi range. If the screen isnt big enough for you, you have the option to Chromecast these videos to any HDMI (Television) device on your connected network. Getting files onto the Nexus is very easy, you can either plug in a USB to micro USB (Wish they had used mini or full size USB as the connector seems flaky). Since Droid has such a wide variety of software available you can also download a file browser such as ES Explorer and copy these over your network (or the Internet) via FTP, or Samba etc.Google is able to offer these durable top notch tablets fairly cheap as they are trying to get their name out. In other words, it comes preloaded with Google apps, works great with Chromecast etc. Another nice thing about being a Google product is that it gets the firmware updates before other devices! These updates usually take 3-4 minutes to install compared to 3-4 hours for a similar firmware update on my Surface RT.
