Unlike the Surface and possibly the iPad is that Droids allow you to choose your internet browser, Mozilla firefox (can sync favorites and history with your desktop), Internet Explore or Google's own Chrome.The learning curve to using these (my first tablet) is pretty quick. These are not my first tablets ever as one vendor shipped me a Surface RT for $75 (instead of a scratch and dented 2012 16GB Nexus 7). I thought the Surface was a heck of a deal until I started using it. The new Metro interface and Windows 8.1RT has all he unfriendliness and bad aspects of the past versions of Windows including being a real resource hog. I do miss a regular keyboard but for light use, the screen keyboard is sufficient. In fact, my wife liked it so much I wound up buying her a Nexus 10 for the 2013 Christmas season.The biggest drawback with the Nexus 7 will likely be charging issue. If you Google this or look at some of the other reviews you will this not an uncommon problem. I believe the Nexus 7 has a small chip inline with the battery and for some reason it decides to charge at a really low rate. This seems to be exasperated when the battery is really low or dead and you plug in the charger. If you unplug the charger from the wall and plug it back in a few times during the charge cycle it usually seems to clear this up. If this is the case Google could easily just make a charger that cuts power briefly once an hour and this would allow the chip to work with some battery behind it and hopefully make the right decision about how much current to draw. Or better yet, why not have a charge light on the charger to let you know you its drawing 2a? This used to happen often for me even though I am a daily charger (my Treo 650 that I still use runs on two charges a  month) often to get annoying. The docking base they sell for it seems to have cut back on this and I have only had it not fully charge overnight once on me.

Reviews.Title: The best part of my life.
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I've had my Nexus 7 (2012) for 7 months now, and hands down, it's the favorite thing I own. It has completely nullified my laptop with the exception of word processing. It's light, clean, responsive, totally free of bloaty software, and the picture is so crisp and vibrant. Blows any Kindle out of the water, guaranteed. (shh, don't tell Amazon I said that!)I watch Netflix and it's awesome, reading is great (I suggest getting an app like Luminosity to lower the brightness lower than the tablet itself will allow).HOWEVER, Amazon Prime Instant Video is NOT made available for this device, so beware. ALSO, flash player doesn't work on Chrome or Firefox on this device, so you have to download a weird browser if you want to watch project free tv or anything like that.I love it so much. Buy one! Buy ten. Buy a million.

Reviews.Title: Worked after half a day inside the water!!!
Reviews.Author: Mayara
Reviews.Content: I need to share with the world how happy I am with my Nexus.When I purchased it I wasn`t sure if I did a good choice because of the bad reviews talking about factory defects.I was moving to Brasil, so it would be a pain to exchange anything.I couldn`t be more wrong, not only the tablet worked great, but also surprise me.2 months ago I had a serious car accident where my car end up under a bridge into the water, needless to explain that last thing I worried about was my Nexus inside the car.The next day, almost half a day after the accident I went to the car. My brother found the tablet and put it on the backpack. I told him to throw it away, and that had no chance to the thing work again after all that time inside the water.Well my friends, once more I was wrong,Today, almost two months after the accident my brother gets home saying that have a Xmas gift for me.Surprise!!! It`s my Nexus!He told me he put it on rice few hours after finding it, and last week he decided he would give the tablet a try. So he opened it and spend 4 days cleaning the dirty from the inside. And when he finished:Tadam!!!My nexus is working perfectly!!! He didn`t replace any piece, only cleaned it.I can`t tell how amazed and happy I am.I even baptized my nexus Michael Phelps for being such a great swimmer.All my books, apps, musics and pictures are there. Saved like if nothing had happened, just waiting for me to play.Now, yeah! My brother did an outstanding work, he should be hired for a huge tech company, but only a great product could survive more than 12 hours under the water.Besides being my personal 7 inch hero, even before the accident I notice that the touchscreen is great (better than IPAD), the voice response is super cool (I love ask google to google stuff) and the size is perfect. I really enjoy reading on it, and I am the old kind of person who still buy paper book.Before buying it I was worried about space, but I never get even close to my limit of 32gb, and I have a cable that allows me to connect my pen drive on it.So if I can tell anything about this tablet is: My best amazon purchase!I Would recommend it even for Steve Jobs.PS: Real costumer, real history and real fishes were swimming around the tablet under the river.PS2: My car didn`t get such a great review unfortunately.

Reviews.Title: Not reliable at all, worst device every owned
Reviews.Author: Leigh
Reviews.Content: Since I bought the Nexus 7, there have been two Android updates, first 4.3, and then 4.4.  Every time there is an update, the auto rotation will stop working, and then there are suggestions you reset the device. Even that does not always help. Apps also crashes.  I have the minimum number of apps installed.  This is the worst experience I ever had with a device.  If you have to loss data all the time due to it the updates and you have to uninstall or reset your device, then it does not even qualify as a toy.  Not sure what the problem is, and google would never give you an answer.  What a shame!

Reviews.Title: Great Tablet
Reviews.Author: SurlyHiker "SurlyHiker"
Reviews.Content: I've owned a first gen Nexus 7 since November of 2012 and I love this tablet.  I also own a 10" TransformerPad TF300 and the Nexus 7 blows it out of the water in terms of stability and performance, despite the fact that they have essentially the same internals.Google updates this tablet immediately upon new Android versions becoming available and I will never again consider a third party Android device for that reason.The one issue I have had (and continue to have) with this tablet is that the auto screen brightness is a little flaky and the screen brightness will change sometimes for no apparent reason and the resulting flicker is annoying.  At one point I turned off the auto screen brightness which resolved the problem, but then you have to adjust the brightness manually for different lighting conditions.

Reviews.Title: Fast and functional!
Reviews.Author: Feike Witlam
Reviews.Content: This ASUS Nexus 7 has all the features you can expect from a Tablet.Handy size and real fast in getting online.The 2012 model is a price!

Reviews.Title: Wonderfull!
Reviews.Author: Ivon
Reviews.Content: It's a very good product.It's my first tablet, and it's just what I expected! I really recommend this tablet!

Reviews.Title: great product
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: This is my second one.  I broke the glass on the first one but I love it.  I read all of my books on there.  It has plenty of memory, the video is awesome.

Reviews.Title: An ok Tablet nothing special here
Reviews.Author: Asif
Reviews.Content: In every aspect this tablet gets an okay mark and with a few let downs and disappointments.First of all, There is a quad-core Tegra 3 processor in it but it seems the system is not quad core processing feature or its just buzz word to fool everyone.Second, buttery smoothness shown in demos is just when no apps are running. if you have 2 or more apps running like facebook and skype or browser or skype there is tick sound in skype voice communication and it freezes a little while during this type of operation. But its not saying its not usable but its kinda annoying.I have used android with dual core processor which performed better than this.At this time the Chrome browser is no where near the PC part, its too damn slow and unresponsive and why have they removed the android browser with chrome.the google NOW said to the best feature of android, is too damn slow on this device to be any useful for regualar use. rather than using it to search google its better and faster in a browser.Gaming performance overall is good.However I have put mostly the negative parts but there are many good aspects of this tablet which you can find anywhere on the web but the good ones in no way overweights the bad ones. Rather they are quite heavy.the price of this should be less than $150 then it would be justified cause its without a back camera.

Reviews.Title: Great tablet at a low cost
Reviews.Author: Chris Figueroa
Reviews.Content: I bought this before I went on a trip with friends for something to do in the car. This thing is great! Fast, Great graphics and is well worth the money. Its solid which is always a plus. If you are looking for a really good tablet and do not want to spend a lot. Buy this tablet you will not be disappointed

Reviews.Title: Nexus 7 2012
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I purchased this tablet on release day, & very much like it.Things about it I like:Gorilla Glass screenSnappy processorEnough memory for multitasking.Sturdy BuildThere is only one thing I do not like:How some things on the web do not display properly. (Videos, etc)A great buy for a fun Android tablet.

Reviews.Title: Loved it until Android 4.3 UPdate
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "reviewer"
Reviews.Content: I really loved my Nexus 7 until the Android 4.3 update came along.  Before the update, I had no problems whatsoever.  Granted, I only read books and played games so I don't know if there was any serious lag in watching movies or TV.  Supposedly the Android 4.3 update was supposed to fix a lot of issues and make the unit much faster and improved oh so many ways.  Well, unfortunately for me, it completely disabled my ability to access WiFi in any capacity.  I contacted Google support and they suggested a factory reboot and to contact Asus.  Asus had no clue how to fix the issue but suggested a factory reboot.  SO, I did the factory reboot.  Lost every book and game on my unit.  :( Now the unit only sits on the Select WiFi screen permanently.  Asus  had me send the unit in for repair. This was on July 30, 2013.I finally received my Nexus 7 back today, August 15, 2013.  I reestablished the WiFi connection and the unit updated again...and the Android 4.3 wiped it out again.  I would have thought they would have fixed this issue when they had the unit at the service center.  After all, that was the reason I sent the unit in.  Now I have to send it back to Asus for repair again - at myown cost!  Needless to say, I am not happy with this entire situation.  I'm not sure if the 2013 Nexus 7 is having the same issue with the Android 4.3 update but unless you never update your unit, I would not recommend purchasing the 2012 Nexus 7 even at a highly discounted price.

Reviews.Title: Just okay
Reviews.Author: Erica
Reviews.Content: I wanted a tablet to watch TV on, stream movies, and play games...about a week after getting it my HBO Go stopped working:(  Argghhh! When my tablet updated itself about 3 apps I had downloaded stopped working...its not that the tablet didn't work right...but I guess its just a bit to new for certain app companies to keep up? Idk. All in all it is a good tablet...just wish it would run some of my preferred apps.

Reviews.Title: Great tablet, great price
Reviews.Author: J. Martens
Reviews.Content: Despite being a loyal Amazon fan, I decided to replace my Kindle Fire (first generation) with the Nexus 7 in 2012. So happy I did. While the fire was a great device for consuming Amazon digital content, this tablet is a great all around device. The base Android operating system is a dream to use....much better than my Android phones that get mucked by up Samsung and Verizon.The size of this tablet is great for personal use, but i find it lacking for business use. All the hardware is great, love that it has GPS. Except, I do find myself wishing it had a rear camera.Best value out there, get it and be happy!

Reviews.Title: Quite Perfect!!!!
Reviews.Author: Juan Pablo Guerrero
Reviews.Content: I must say that 1b32-4g its a quiet perfect device. The things that I can't do with it:1.- Install some basic apps. like whatsapp, some camera apps like zoom camera 360 and others2.- Phone calls. dialer, not to make a phone call, just to input codes in the dialer.3.- It receives sms, but It's not possible to answer them. Maybe I have to install an app.4.- Its not possible to share your internet connection using your 3g sim card. not even USB.I will update after some time...C-yaJuan PVenezuela

Reviews.Title: Replaces broken e-book reader. For very little more this gives you an excellent reader, whole computer & amazing movie screen!
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "Escucho"
Reviews.Content: There is a lot to learn if this is your first Android device. This is my second Nexus 7. The good news is that the Nexus 7 can be configured to:- replace your ebook reader. I love the Kindle app for it. As it comes, the Nexus 7 is a bit too bright for reading at night but there is an app to custom dim the screen further to make it just right for your eyes.- replace a laptop computer. With a touch-screen, such simple matters as selecting text to cut copy or paste can be <<< utterly maddening.>>> However, these routine tasks become easy, even quite pleasant, with a decent external mouse and good external keyboard. Good peripherals take up very little briefcase space and really make the Nexus 7 an excellent road-warrior. An OTG cable and app change the charging micro-USB port into an external access port for reading and writing memory sticks and even powered hard disk drives. 16GB is plenty with such external storage. When not working, the Nexus 7 tablet is such a handy package you are most likely to have it, well, right at hand.- The screen is remarkable for watching movies and is very nice for video calls (Skype, Tango, etc.) I am pleased the screen is also very readable for texts, emails and browsing the Internet. (My eyes really are those of a senior although my younger-than-my-age brain is shocked to see how old I am in the mirror... :)All of this for about $50 more than only an e-reader! Do look up the LONG Nexus 7 review here on Amazon which has a Very Large Number of comments -- because that author gives superb technical advice.As a Windows computer guru and Mac aficionado, I did not expect to be so impressed with the Nexus 7, but I am. When I ordered this Nexus 7 I was already aware that an improved version would be coming soon. I bought this one anyway because the value-to-price ratio is so positive. I came to depend on my first Nexus 7 so much, that for the price I wanted a spare machine I could configure identically. (Two Nexus 7 cost me less than a laptop. Spend $200 for a spare tire, professionally speaking? Sure.) This time I sprang for the 32 GB model (my other Nexus 7 is fine with 16GB) because when travelling I can sometimes be uncluttered of peripherals to use the additional storage for movies, downloaded programs and music.Do get a good case for it. (The Nexus 7's lovely screen is not the latest Gorilla glass.) For its fine protection and versatility, I very much like the Moko Slim Fit case which I've reviewed for the Nexus 7.Android is something else but definitely worth learning to use, so be patient getting through the learning curve.The Nexus 7 is most highly recommended.

Reviews.Title: Best 7 inch.
Reviews.Author: Carlos Aguirre
Reviews.Content: I bought it as a gift for my girlfriend and she loves it, the size is perfect to hold it with one hand, is fast, it doesnt gets laggy as many people complain (I also have one for more than a year) and with the new update 4.3 it gets even faster. Battery lasts long, screen has a very nice resolution low weight, perfect partner for travels. Beats any ipad.

Reviews.Title: I love my Nexus 7
Reviews.Author: Lori Pruitt
Reviews.Content: Before I bought the Nexus 7 I shopped around for other tablets. This small tech wonder was the perfect buy. It's thin and portable and has as much processing power as most desktops. I can do spreadsheets, watch movies play top of the line games or even set up a streaming video.  Lots of apps are available to really customize your Nexus.Cons: The touchscreen isn't Gorilla Glass, so you'll need a case to help protect it.  A screen protector is also a good idea to help against smudges.Forward facing camera seems awkward, but I guess its more for a webcam feel than an actual camera. No camera app was installed but that was easily remedied with a trip to the Amazon App store or GooglePlay.All in all, I am extremely happy with my Nexus 7! it does everything I want when I need it. :)

Reviews.Title: A useful tablet
Reviews.Author: LMP
Reviews.Content: I bought this for my husband as a gift and he absolutely loves it. The only downfall and hence the reason it got four stars instead of five, is that the battery dies pretty quickly and the charger is pretty short. It can be charged via your pc though. The apps are fantastic and the images are clear. I am thinking of purchasing one for myself.

Reviews.Title: Two in a row with major software issue
Reviews.Author: Steven Parker
Reviews.Content: A year ago(?), I bought the Nexus 7 16gb version.  After a week, you would try to swipe the tablet on, and it would stay on for 1 millisecond and then go back to the swipe screen.  It would do this endlessly until at some point it would actually stay on.  I called Google, they had me do a soft, then a hard reset, and then when neither of the above worked, they sent me a replacement.  That one worked.  Last week I bought another one - Nexus 7 32gb model and guess what?  Same exact problem!  I called Google - same thing - the hard reset did nothing, and they're sending me another one (refurbished?).  The guy on the Google line said he never heard of this problem, and yet 2 out of 2 I bought one year apart had the same problem.  How can a product have such an out of the box glitch such as this!?  Otherwise I like it and the price is right.  But what a pain in the meantime!

Reviews.Title: Great Little Tablet
Reviews.Author: trianj
Reviews.Content: Decided to go with this one instead of an IPad.  Needless to say it was half the price.  The tablet is well constructed and operates flawlessly.  An excellent value.  My only complaint is that my wife has confiscated it for her use.  She loves it.  Also purchased the case for it which also is very well constructed and useful.  No complaints here.

Reviews.Title: My screen flickers and have read other posts on Google plus that others do too
Reviews.Author: Gregory A. Gaxiola
Reviews.Content: My wife has an iPad mini and I have the regular size iPad third gen. Model. I wanted a more portable device also so bought the Nexus 7. However I am completely dissatisfied with the quality of the product. I will wait, save my money and get a iPad mini when they finally release their Retina display. I also bout a regular size tablet running Google and am not happy with the software apps compared to the iPad.

Reviews.Title: Disappointed
Reviews.Author: Sandy Fiems
Reviews.Content: I am very disappointed in this tablet.  It does not hold the charge more than 6 hours.  I have to have it plugged in almost all the time I am at home using it.

Reviews.Title: Great tablet at a great price
Reviews.Author: Stephen B. Fraser "Steve"
Reviews.Content: This is not my first tablet, I have owned and used the iPad, and a Android 10 inch tablet prior to buying this one. I have to say I can't find many things wrong with this one. The Nexus 7 is made by ASUS and everyone knows that ASUS makes top quality products. The size is perfect for holding with one hand and the touchscreen is very responsive even with an aftermarket screen protector on it. Android 4.2 is currently the newest update and it works perfectly. The screen resolution is and I can look at it for hours and not have any issues with eye strain or pain. (Wish I could have said the same thing about my iPad) The 32 GB model offers plenty of storage space on the device and with being over 50% used it is still just as fast and responsive as it was right out of the box. The speaker on the back of the device is adequate and what I would expect from a unit of this quality. The Front facing camera is great for streaming video call via Skype and the clarity is great. There is no rear facing camera but as I have found on a device like this I wouldn't use it even if it did have one. The case has a textured back which makes holding on to the device easy. The battery life is excellent and in my experience with it only going into sleep mode and getting moderate use all day long. I only have to charge it every three days. WiFi works wonderfully and has great range.The only drawbacks I can see are little things like no SD card support. and the software lacks a camera app (though you can get one on the Google app store.)This is a great unit with loads of possibilities. I would recommend it to everyone I know.

Reviews.Title: Simply splendid
Reviews.Author: JVDL
Reviews.Content: First and foremost I wasn't a believer in the need for a tablet. I thought it was mere a hype. Obviously I was wrong. When it came down to me choosing a tablet I was looking to the use it would have for me. I quickly narrowed it down to a 7 inch tablet simply for the ease of use. I find myself "Googling" constantly on my phone while watching TV or a movie. Once my girlfriend got herself an Ipad I got a costumed to the ease of use compared with my phone. Only because of its size it was at times awkward holding the tablet. The nexus 7 resolved all this for me. It was easy to set up with my Google account. The screen is beautiful. I have been editing photos on it. It fits comfortably in my hand which makes it so easier using it while watching TV or being in bed. At this price its well worth the money. Its fast responsive. I use regularly to read pdf files. The price cant be beaten at this point.

Reviews.Title: Researched this heavily, nothing even compares except maybe Apple...
Reviews.Author: hoosier65
Reviews.Content: I never buy anything (especially electronic) without research, research, research! I narrowed it down to three. My final choice was this one was because of the excellent reviews by consumers and experts alike, I knew I wanted a quad core processor vs. the dual core (yes folks it does make a difference, I can actually watch Netflix or YouTube without lag time), 32mg which is way more than enough for even a heavy user,  my son can play high end video games, the swift option of typing like swipe, which is very accurate and nothing short of amazing, love how it feels while holding it doesn't feel like like it is going to easily slip out of your hand, voice recognition, ease of use and the list goes on! I have had it for a week and nothing bad to say about it. Wouldn't have minded the nexus just like it but a 10 inch screen but this is what I could afford so was willing to sacrifice that. No rear camera but not an issue for me because I have an 8 mp on my iPhone 5. So I feel I can sacrifice a bigger screen of lesser quality. About a year ago I purchased a Samsung 10 inch tablet. I ended up sending it back. It was so slow it couldn't handle anything.  This little gem so far can handle everything. I am anxious to get the case/keyboard I ordered for it. Then it will be complete! I just have nothing bad or negative to say...love it!!!

Reviews.Title: It is perfect
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I have had my Nexus 7 since February and I love it. It does everything I need. My husband has Asus Transformer and it is just to big for me. I love the size of the Nexus and it works so well. I use it to read and watch movies when I am on the treadmill. I use it at work as well. It makes it easy to live in a paper free world. I would rather use my Nexus then paper.

Reviews.Title: Words fail me...THIS IS ASTOUNDING!
Reviews.Author: KB7RKY
Reviews.Content: Like many of you, I purchased a cheap Chinese knock-off because I was too frugal to sink my hard-earned cash into a name-brand tablet, or I didn't want to buy into the iProduct craze with one of those overhyped devices.Oh sure...El Cheapo works great for awhile with its' odd quirks and eccentricities, but when the A10 Allwinner device takes a dump and destroys your files, you either curse it out, try to find the root cause of the problem, or just give up and buy another cheap knock-off because, again, you're too cheap to get a real device (or don't want an overpriced electronic device).In my case, I tried everything humanly possible to rescue my files from the jaws of defeat, all to no avail. El Cheapo went to its' grave with nearly all my files...thankfully, TF/MicroSD Cards are fairly cheap, and interchangeable with other Android devices, so I was able to transfer those to Old Reliable (an earlier-version Android device I had purchased last year). I then turned to my Facebook Groups, asking what would be a suitable replacement for the A10 Allwinner that had just died. The overwhelming majority said "Get A Nexus 7." Well, I was understandably hesitant...after all, it was relatively expensive ($250+), but the features were far better than the cheap knock-offs (1280X800 display, NVIDIA GeForce Video Processor, a *QUAD-CORE* processor, long battery life, wi-fi, etc.) Well, truthfully, I didn't get much farther than "NVidia" before I decided this was going to be my next tablet, as I have NVidia graphics processors in both my desktop and laptop computers. The 32GB internal storage was a real bonus, as was the USB OTG feature (I suppose it has a SATA SSD that could be expanded, but I'm not going to crack the case to find out). The OS is incredibly easy to use...if you've used an Android platform for a few months (or years), it won't be hard to adapt (unlike those incredibly confusing iProducts).I've not used all the features as yet (such as the camera) as I'm still restoring my previously-purchased apps to the device.The one big downside I can see (so far) is the inability for this tablet to accept standard or micro SD Cards. Whether this was intentional, or an oversight on Google's part, I don't know. Perhaps this feature could/should be included in future Nexus Devices.Overall, I'm happier with this new tablet than I ever was with my old El Cheapo. I've loaded music onto it, and am listening to Meat Loaf's "Hits Out Of Hell", with all the clarity of the best of CD Players. I think I'll download Skype next and have a chat with my brother in California...EDIT, 5/23/13:Another Amazon User (Kinchas) suggested getting Nexus Media Importer, as did many other Nexus Users. I have to say, that has been one of the most useful apps I've ever used. I still think Google's choice of not including an SD/Micro SD slot is a terrible oversight, but with Media Importer, you're not limited to just a few measly gigs of storage (it was able to handle a relatively small 1GB thumb drive with all my Mythbusters pics on it very well), but, potentially up to the terabytes range...and I do have a 3TB drive not being used. I also like the tablet's ability to use wireless storage drives, like the Kingston Wi-Drive. Granted, you have to set it up like a wi-fi and download the app, but once that's done, it works great.Another downside I've found is the USB port itself. There's only the one micro USB port. Sure, it's very useful for charging or transferring files (both at the same time if you connect the tablet to your computer), but if you want to charge the battery *and* use an external storage device...well, that could present a problem. Perhaps a second USB port would be beneficial.

Reviews.Title: Becoming one of my favorites!
Reviews.Author: Judy L.
Reviews.Content: At this point in time I have a number of tablets including a Kindle Fire HD 7", a Mini iPad, a 10" Asus TF300, and an iPad 3. The Kindle Fire HD was my first 7" tablet. I got it because it was relatively less expensive than most of the other 7" tablets, and I wanted to see if I liked the 7" vs. the 10" tablet. As it turned out, I really like the size of the 7" tablet because of the portability, and it's less weight to hold for reading. Next I got the iPad Mini. I have to say that I love the iPads. Even though you are tied into iTunes for downloads, the applications seem to be more fully developed than most of the comparable Android apps, and the latest version of iTunes is really handy for organizing apps, music, etc, and can also be used to organize apps on the iPads. As many reviewers have already stated, comparing the IOS system of the iPads and the Android systems is like trying to compare apples to oranges.Even though I wouldn't part with my iPads, I do enjoy the Android devices. I posted a review of the 7" Kindle Fire HD shortly after I got it, and before I got the other 7" tablets including the Nexus 7. I love my Mini iPad, but I wanted a 7" android tablet. When I found out that the Nexus 7 was made by Asus, I was immediately intrigued because I have the Asus TF300 and have been impressed with the Asus tablets. I considered the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2, but after comparing the specs with those of the Nexus 7, decided that the Nexus 7 was the superior tablet.Having had the Nexus 7 for a couple of weeks, I have found that it is very similar to the Asus TF300 as far as quality, setup, and operation. Since the Nexus 7 is Google oriented, it has a sidebar on the right side that contains primarily Google links, and on the left side of the screen there is a bar for the voice Google search. I don't have a problem with this because I use many of the Google services. Aside from this, the home screen and other screens are completely customizable. Folders can be set up to group applications, and they can be placed on any of the multiple screens available. The system is very fast and responsive. I haven't gotten into rooting the system because I haven't had a need for it. I don't think the risk is worth the possible benefits.As for charging the system, it doesn't require anything special. If you have a mini USB to USB cable, you can connect it to any A/C adapter that you have that takes a USB connector. I use the same cable for charging my phone, the Nexus 7, my keyboard, and my mouse. It does not require a special charging cable as many of the other tablets do.As compared to the Kindle Fire HD, the Nexus 7 has much more flexibility, and is much more customizable. The screen of the Kindle Fire HD cannot be customized as  far as showing applications that you have available. The Kindle Fire HD has one screen that shows a turntable of apps that you have used, and they are shown in the sequence that you used them. If you try an app and don't want to use it on a regular basis, you have to remove it from the turntable. There is no organization other than the sequence that you open apps. If you remove an app and want to use it again, you have to go to the list of installed apps to find it. The same is true for videos, music, and anything else you may have on the tablet. In addition, Google android apps are not compatible with the Kindle Fire HD. So apps used are confined to the Amazon world. The Nexus 7 can use both Google and Amazon android apps.The only downside that I have found for the Nexus 7 is that not all Google android apps are compatible with this tablet, but they are for my Asus TF300 tablet and for my phone. This may change with future updates to software. I did buy this tablet with the AT&T; sim card, and bought it directly from Google because the price was less than the Amazon price. I would highly recommend this tablet for anyone looking for a versatile and high quality 7" tablet that doesn't have a huge price tag.UPDATE!!I have had the Nexus 7 for a couple more weeks, and it is still one of my favorite of the tablets that I have. It has all of the flexibility of the Asus TF300 tablet and the size makes it extremely portable. At least for now, this is one of the tablets that I wouldn't part with. The Nexus 7 is compatible with both Google apps and Amazon android apps. Whereas, the Kindle HD is compatible only with Amazon Kindle apps, and not even all of them. The apps must be specifically compatible for the Kindle HD. I also find it curious that the Kindle app for reading books is much nicer on the iPads and android tablets than it is on the Kindle. You would think that the Kindle app on a Kindle tablet would be superior to what it is on other tablets. Go figure.

Reviews.Title: Android finally has me convinced!
Reviews.Author: samantha
Reviews.Content: I wanted a tablet, but couldn't even fathom spending so much money on an Ipad and didn't want an e-reader because the app selection isn't as great. I am so glad I bought this tablet I have had it since December 2012 and use it constantly, the only complaint I had was I had an iphone and I couldn't get the most out of Google Play because of it. I am now a proud owner of a Samsung S3 as well as this Nexus and couldn't be happier from the Apple to Android switch best decision I have ever made! Another slight disadvantage is that it isn't the most popular of tablets so it is hard to find accesories specifically for this tablet, but this is coming from someone who used to have an iphone and they have too many options.

Reviews.Title: Almost perfect
Reviews.Author: George A. Ector
Reviews.Content: First what I like: speed, screen, battery life, size, weight.What's not to love? The camera. There was no camera app loaded so, at first I couldn't even figure out how to access the camera.On top of that the camera is only front facing. This is not a deal-breaker for me but, that is what kept me from giving it 5 stars.

Reviews.Title: Awesome.
Reviews.Author: raw
Reviews.Content: Its all you expect and some more. Just has the right size, great battery, great apps, great screen. just beautiful.

Reviews.Title: Excellent product (other than absense of rear camera)
Reviews.Author: GoodProducts-BadProducts
Reviews.Content: Excellent. I have been using Nexus 7 for several months now. Although there is no rear camera, it is has become very handy around house, and during my train/bus ride. It has effectively replaced my laptop. Unlike laptops, no time is lost in booting or turning it on, convenient to check all my hotmail and gmail emails at one place. Also excellent for reading books (pdf or other formats), listening to music, play apps, etc. Battery life is excellent. Unlike my laptop, it is not bulky to use during train or bus rides (not much noticeable by others). The 7-inch size is way convenient than the iPad size. Also, this Nexus is much much lighter than iPad (holding iPad while reading would require 2 hands, but you can grab Nexus 7 by one hand).

Reviews.Title: Leave the Laptop at home...
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I have been an avid tablet user since the iPad 1st Gen but the Nexus 7 has finally hit the sweet spot and I can now travel with this device instead of a laptop.  It travels in my jacket pocket, it connects to a mouse and keyboard when I need to sit down and compose docs and emails.  I can watch two, two hour movies flying coast to coast and still have 50% battery left when I land.  The best part though comes from combining this device with apps like Gmail, Evernote, DropBox and the HubDesk hosted desktop service.  I can now leave my laptop at home, using the Android apps to keep in touch on the move and the HubDesk desktop along with a Bluetooth keyboard and mouse to run full desktop versions of Open Office apps, Firefox and Chrome when I need them.

Reviews.Title: Great product
Reviews.Author: Jessica Linzmeier
Reviews.Content: For the price what you get is amazing, one of the best on the market.  Everything can run on it.

Reviews.Title: Poor Quality
Reviews.Author: John Cargill "J Balls"
Reviews.Content: I bought this a little over a month ago and I am having major screen issues with ghosting and back light bleeding. I have never owned a tablet with these issue before including Samsung/Archos/Cowon. This tells me the component(s) of this device are of poor/cheap quality. For an electronic device to fail after only one I find that to be pathetic!!

Reviews.Title: Asus support could use some help
Reviews.Author: Teddy Striker
Reviews.Content: Device takes 24 hours to charge, did an RMA, got it back with exactly the same problem.I'd avoid Asus like the plague no matter how nice or inexpensive the device is.edited:2nd RMA is a new or perfect condition refurb.  It took too long and they failed the first time, but they did eventually solve the problem.  I raised the review from 1 to 3 stars and toned down the harsh wording

Reviews.Title: Exceptional 7" tablet
Reviews.Author: Barsu
Reviews.Content: I purchased this tablet from another website but seeing as I buy most everything from Amazon I thought I should leave a review for my new Nexus 7 here.I replaced an older 7" tablet that I had been happy with until they upgraded to Jelly Bean and then it just became too slow. I had read so many great reviews on the Nexus 7 that I decided to buy it. I got the 32gb because it doesn't have an external micro sd card slot (which is the only negative thing I have to say about it. The Nexus is fast, runs Jelly Bean extremely smooth, has a beautiful screen, music plays beautifully with very good volume .. I know that's a lot of beautifuls in the last sentence :-) . I couldn't be happier. And for the money it can't be beat. All my apps are android so I wouldn't even consider an iPad and like I said, for the money I'm sure you couldn't find anything that even comes close ... even for a considerable amount more.All said I'm glad I started having problems with my other tablet, which is a good brand, because I am so happy with my Nexus 7.I also bought a case for it from here on Amazon which I had only planned on using when my Nexus was in my purse to keep the screen from getting scratched. Now I can't imagine ever taking it off. It has very cool features like automatically putting it to sleep when closed then waking when opening, along with great angles for watching moving or typing. I got it in white which looks very cool and expensive. It is listed as: "MoKo Slim-fit Cover Case for Google Nexus 7 Android Tablet by Asus, White (with Automatic Sleep/Wake Function, Protective Hardback, Built-in Multi-angle Stand, Elastic Hand Strap, and Stylus Loop)" Be sure to check it out .. you definitely won't be sorry.I know this was long but I am so happy with both products I couldn't make it any shorter.

Reviews.Title: Nexzus 7
Reviews.Author: Ms. Thomas "Ms. Thomas"
Reviews.Content: Love it but the instructions doesn't tell you everything you need to do to make it true fully functional. You have to add a few apps for certain things to make it work properly. Jus go to YouTube like I did to learn your tablet and what apps are good for you. Love it though.

Reviews.Title: 70.00 cheaper on Google Play store.
Reviews.Author: Diego the Reviewer "Doug"
Reviews.Content: Why are you folks paying 70 more to this Amazon 3rd party seller, when you can purchase it for 199.99 from the Google Play store?I bought it there, and love it by the way, but wanted to mention that first to you all.I was originally deciding between the Galaxy Tab II from Costco (they had it for 189.00), but chose the Nexus 7.  Much faster processor and better screen resolution.  I am very happy.

Reviews.Title: Bigger screen, slower video streaming than Galaxy Nexus phone
Reviews.Author: PJA_in_Boston "PJA_in_Boston"
Reviews.Content: Pros: Solid construction; Nice screen, good for e-reading; Android V4.2Cons: Except for screen size, less functional than my Samsung Galaxy Nexus - e.g., no 3G or 4G (with my carrier, Verizon); SLOWER VIDEO STREAMING - hangs frequently enough to render it virtually useless for the purpose.Conclusion: Returned it to Google, from whom I bought it (under their 15-day return policy), in spite of a 15% restocking fee.  My Galaxy Nexus (with extended battery) does the job for me, AND it includes a phone, all in one very portable package.

Reviews.Title: A Lovely Tablet for a Decent Price
Reviews.Author: Mr. X-CLU$IV
Reviews.Content: I got this tablet recently, and it is a great tablet.  Before you buy this tablet, though, I should mention the exclusion of the micro-SD.  This is a problem, mostly because if you run out of space, you'll have to delete app after app just to store more, especially games.  Now that I got that out of the way, let me say why I love this tablet.  This is an excellent tablet for gaming.  So far games that lagged on my Xperia Play runs silky smooth, thanks to the Tegra 3 processor.  The screen is the perfect size for me, because it's big for typing my papers, but small and light enough to carry it around anywhere.  The battery is also quite good.  I don't have a good estimate, but could be all day battery life in standby, since it was fully charged before and after a two hour day of classes without Wi-Fi.  I didn't like Google Play Music but after trying this tablet, and finally downloading some of my free songs on the device, I grown accustomed to it.  I also grew accustomed to Swype, and I began loving Gesture Typing at first try.  There are a lot more to say about this tablet, but I don't feel like typing all night.  If you don't mind the exclusion of the micro-SD slot, get this tablet.  You won't be disappointed.

Reviews.Title: Stopped working
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "Sand"
Reviews.Content: Loved it for 5 months.  Then it suddenly stopped working properly.  Won't charge, won't reset, won't respond correctly to touch.  Of course the warranty won't cover it.I'm pretty ticked, because for what I paid, I expect more than 5 months of use.

Reviews.Title: Asus support is bad..........
Reviews.Author: J. Curtin
Reviews.Content: Everything was great for the first two months then it would not charge.  After a very long wait on their site to get a return number I got one along with  a long  list of  instructions and warnings to include the charger etc. They kept it for ten days and then sent it back to me with no charger.  Another long wait on the chat line and an even longer wait before they took responsibility for the missing charger.  They said they would send one right out, I'm into the second week and no charger. Their literature it's full of warnings not to use any other charger.AMAZON'S RESPONSE IS WE'LL GIVE YOU A TEN DOLLAR COUPON AS LONG AS YOU ACCEPT AN UNUSABLE TABLET!I would not buy from Asus again.While I chatted with Amazon tonight I tried the chat line at Asus again, no response..com

Reviews.Title: Thoroughly satisfied
Reviews.Author: Northwoods
Reviews.Content: I've had my Nexus for seven months now and it has proven to be nothing like what I got it for... Sounds bad, right?  I got it to replace my Palm Pilot, the third I'd owned.  The thing no longer held a charge and I was about to buy my fourth charger.  So, decided I should modernize and get a tablet.  I DID NOT WANT A SMARTPHONE.  Why? Because when I need a phone, it better work.  Smartphones (and the Nexus) need to be charged daily and face it, if they are being used heavily, they may need to be charged during the day.  I live in an area that is decidedly rural with lots of cellphone dead zones.  The plain old cellphone gets way more reliable connection and battery life in this environment.  But I needed my contacts and calendar with me and I'd had a couple of experiences where Internet access was suddenly needed on trips.  So, got the Nexus.  As it has turned out, I am using it all day long and rarely turning on the PC anymore.  This has actually improved my health as I can move from one position to another easily and reduce my incidence of migraines from sitting in one position for too long.I have read these reports about slowness as the Nexus ages.  What I'd like to know is, how many apps do these people have on their devices?  Did they pay the extra fee to get rid of the ads?  Are the apps polling all day long for updates?  Because I'm not seeing these problems.  I regularly check to see what is running and if an app is constantly running when not being used, it may go on the chopping block.  Same with ads.. They better have an ad-free version.  I also check permissions for the apps before I download them and I prevent auto-upgrades to recheck what new permissions are being added each time.  Ripped Facebook off because of its increasing privacy intrusions, in fact.  Anyway, before you believe all those reports, find out what kind of mess those users have created by unthinkingly adding every cool app they come across.  After all, you can install and remove them once you lose interest in them and still reinstall them later.

Reviews.Title: Not as advertised and ultimately defective
Reviews.Author: Barry Bayer
Reviews.Content: The device was supposed to come with Android System 4.2.2.  Alas, it had only 4.1.1.After many attempts at upgrading OTA, Google Product Supportclaimed it may have a defective boot loader (whatever that is).Asus was willing to repair it, but would take at least two weeks to do itand wouldn't pay postage to them.I elected to return the unit.  Looks like I will purchase a new Nexus 7 with considerableenhancement once available in the next couple of months.

Reviews.Title: So far, so good, AND still going strong!
Reviews.Author: Barry E. Sharrow
Reviews.Content: This is my first Android device so, I'm still learning a lot about it and cannot evaluate it's capabilities with any degree of expertise.  After a week or so, it seems to be holding up and doing what it is supposed to do and that seems to be that it keeps running.  Before my purchase, I read a lot of the "one-star" reviews and finally decided that most of the negativity was due to over expectation and stupidity rather than bad luck.  I have been waiting for my Nexus 7 to summarily quit on me but so far, it is going strong.If "battery problems" arise, I know they will be caused by the possibility of a loosened connector and can easily be repaired by opening the case with a guitar pick and correcting the defect.  Apparently, if you mishandle your Nexus 7 and knock the battery loose, it is possible to dislodge one of the battery connectors, causing it to become intermittent and/or disconnected altogether.By reading many of the "fixes" for this malady, I have come to the conclusion that one of the battery leads is a trifle short and if the battery shifts, the connector is pulled loose.  NO BIG DEAL!  My take on this is that, like all OEM's, ASUS buys their components from various souces and does final assembly at one or more of their facilities.  In all likelihood, the original design was flawless but as battery technology improved, the newer batteries became slightly smaller and the locations of the connectors changed.  Thus, the battery was held in place by some double-stick tape and one of the battery leads was just long enough to be able to do it's job.  Again, no big deal, and I figured that IF I had this problem, I'd just open that puppy with a guitar pick and take a look.I like to take stuff apart anyway and tightening connectors is just part of normal maintenance so far as I'm concerned.  If needs be, I can lengthen the offending lead, resecure the battery etc.. And then, I know how to replace the battery when it actually does poop out.In a few months, if nothing catastrophic happens, I'll add to this review and probably upgrade the rating to 5 stars.  Naturally, by that time, the new Nexus 7 equivalent will be out, with all sorts of better bells and whistles.  If I like the Android system, I will consider getting the newest hardware but I'll keep my present Nexus 7 for a back-up, knowing that I can take it apart and keep it running.Besides loading a slug of "aps," I did upgade the software to 4.2.2.1, and it was a piece of cake.  This was probably because I decided to order my Nexus 7 through Amazon, paying an extra $10, just to be sure that I got the most recent hardware issued from the factory.  I like factory upgrades and Asus is good at keeping them current.More to follow.UPDATE!:I've given it another star - for longevity, not features.My wife has not been able to kill our Nexus 7 yet.  It still takes a full charge, and has not caught fire or done any of the other scary things that the collective naysayers complain about.Maybe buying from the best source really does pay off!A word to the wise etc.:Beware of Apps bearing permissions.  Fewer is better and read those "permissions" carefully.  These "Apps" both free and costly, can really screw up your device, and your life!  The Net is a dangerous place but for the vigilant and prepared, it can be a useful adventure.  Complacency can and will "get cha"! 'nuff said.

Reviews.Title: Very good tablet
Reviews.Author: Charles Slater
Reviews.Content: This is a review of the Nexus 7 tablet, branded Google, made by Asus, 7" with 32GB storage.  I am mainly comparing this model to the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2, a 7" with 8 GB storage, but with an expansion slot.  I recently acquired the Galaxy model, and reviewed and returned it.  Recent builds of the Android operating system do not make good use of storage expansion.  You may not install apps to it, and many apps which write data cannot be configured to write to it.  While you can use the storage to copy large media files, I felt that the 8 GB available for apps was too limiting.  so I returned the Galaxy and acquired the Nexus.The Nexus is a near ideal 7" tablet.  Android runs beautifully on it, with apps opening noticeably snappier than on the Galaxy.  The processor seems faster and the screen resolution is higher.  Additionally the rear of the unit, with a kind of a textured rubber is friendlier for holding the unit.  I don't want to be too disparaging of the Galaxy, as it is a strong and capable unit.  I just feel that the Nexus is better.  (As I write this, there is word of a Samsung Galaxy 3, so the market is rapidly evolving).The Nexus has the latest version of Android (Jelly Bean), and can be set to automatically update the OS and any apps in the background.  Wifi performance has been excellent.  Netflix and HBO streaming video run very well, and it is, of course, an excellent ereader, supporting the Kindle app and others.  The unit has stereo speakers, but for any serious listening, you will want to use headphones.  The audio volume through the speakers is low, and even through headphones it doesn't get really loud.  I am fine with this, and I note also that there are apps available for boosting volume.In short, everything I've thrown at the Nexus has been handled well.

Reviews.Title: Really Enjoying Nexus 7
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I don't own a smart phone, and never used an Android device before. I wanted to buy a small tablet, and the top 3 choices were Kindle Fire HD, iPad Mini, or Nexus 7. Cost is an important part of my decision making, so the iPad Mini was out immediately.I'm sure the Kindle Fire HD is a great product... I've seen them in action and have no doubt I would have been happy with it. However, in the end, I went with the Nexus 7 and I'm glad I did.The Android operating system was new to me, but it's so intuitive that within a few days, I felt very comfortable downloading new apps and trying out all kinds of things, from drawing and sketching to games and productivity tools. The portability and convenience of such a small device is really fun. I take it into the kitchen with me when I'm looking up recipes. Luckily, I already had some really nice Bluetooth headphones and listen to all the music I can imagine on Spotify. I've also uploaded all my music to Google Music. I've watched a couple of TV episodes I missed, and have a Netflix subscription. Also, I'm a Kindle eReader owner (older version), and find that reading my Kindle books (using the Kindle Android App) on the Nexus 7 is wonderful! It's back-lit and really easy on the eyes.I was already a moderate Google user (gmail, drive, docs, Picasa), but when you use the Nexus 7, you start to see the puzzle pieces of the world of Google fit together very nicely. I, like many Google users, have also noticed the huge amount of information Google has collected about me in order to fit me into Google World seamlessly... it's a trade-off, I guess. iPad owners have the same issue with Apple.The battery life of the Nexus 7 is incredible, and better than anticipated. I'm impressed with the overall quality and ease of use, the learning curve is not very steep.The only thing missing, of course, is a camera on the back (there is a front-facing cam for Skype, etc). I've also read many complaints of the lack of an HDMI-out port for connecting to an HDTV.For the price, I think Nexus 7 owners have a beautiful piece of technology that serves many purposes and interests... and ranks right up there with the iPad mini. Great job, Google and Asus.

Reviews.Title: I returned TWO iPad minis
Reviews.Author: Rick
Reviews.Content: This past Christmas I bought my wife an iPad mini because she lives with her ipod touch and the mini had a larger screen (it is in fact just a large iPod touch).  When we opened gifts, she had bought me one too (I was/am an Android smart phone user).  I spent 18 hours over the course of 3 days trying to get them up and running.  It wasn't me.  Each call was "elevated" to a "senior" Apple tech rep.  One mini would not stay connected to wi fi, and the other would not accept photos from my wife's ipod to the mini.  A trip to the Apple Store (45min one way) didn't resolve either problem. I returned them both...and to their credit, there were no issues with the returns.  The wife is back with her iPod touch and I went out and bought myslef a Nexus 7 (after exhaustive research).  This thing is fast, dependable, versatile, looks great, terrific screen resoltion and a joy to work/play with.  I've had it 2 months and won't look at Apple again due to price....and their constant "updates" that inevitably cause us issues on other devices (iphone and ipod touch).  The cost difference is a no brainer ($199 if you skip Amaon's prices).  The biggest push back I get from family members with the ipad mini is the number of apps available.  Be realistic.  I'm exaggerating but if Apple has 400,000 apps and Android has 300,000 apps, who cares.  Apple is wearing off....and if costs don't come down soon, Android will eat them alive....over time.  This table is FANTASTIC and a GREAT VALUE.  But please note, I bought mine at Office Depot.  Amazon prices for this tablet are highway robbery....and I am an avid Amazon shopper but for this device they are way out of line.  Note:  I checked with Staples, Wal Mart, Office Max, Office Depot, etc.  They all have a 14 day return policy.  So if you're not sure, then buy locally for not only price but convenience...at least for this item.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Tablet for an even better price!
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: First of all, let me say that I am typically an Apple person. I am writing this review on my MacBook Air. I own an iPhone5, and have an iPad Third Generation. I bought this tablet over the iPad Mini after much contemplation. I needed a smaller tablet that is more portable for my job. I'm in retail, and frequently I need to look up products online for customers and was growing tired of having to walk to a desktop computer with the customer in tow. I was a little leery of Android from all the reports of malware that is reported on the web. However, I bought my sister a Nexus 7 for Christmas (she was VERY specific). I only handled it once, but I was impressed with the fluidity and screen resolution. After a few weeks, I asked her if she liked her tablet. She was so excited to tell me that she was very happy with the Nexus 7.This tablet is very light weight. It feels great in your hands. I do recommend getting some kind of case or shell for it because even though it is textured on the back, it does feel at times like it might slip out of your hands. Android Jelly Bean 4.2 comes standard, and my oh my have they made headway with this OS. It's fast, sleek and smooth. It opens programs rapidly and has a beautiful interface with each. I do suggest that you download Avast! mobile security. It is free, and it also happens to be the top rated tablet anti-virus/malware software currently on the market. I did heavy research before my tablet arrived. One great thing that I have noticed with Jelly Bean is that there are fewer apps that run in the background automatically as in previous versions. I still use Task Killer to shut them down to conserve battery life. Speaking of which, I have been able to get almost 7 hours out of a charge of surfing the internet, playing music, etc. The tablet comes with a free HD movie, Ice Age, and I suspect it's to show off the beautiful screen resolution. Some people think they need a 10" tablet to view movies, but I've never felt like I was squinting to watch anything.Apps. They are great. I love Google+, Pinterest, and Instagram. Gmail also runs great and has a simple yet intuitive interface. There are of course the others, such as Facebook and Twitter. I don't personally use Twitter, but I did take a peek at it, and it's quite beautiful and crisp. There a several games that render beautifully on the tablet. I also like the Evernote App, it comes in handy for work and also for my other half and I to send grocery lists to each other.Bottom line: If you want a very portable tablet that is fast, powerful and beautiful, this tablet is the one for you! I paid $270 plus a $59 two year accidental drop, spill and damage warranty from SquareTrade that guarantees my tablet repaired or replaced in five days or they'll pay me $300. I've done my research, and they are the real deal. They receive excellent reviews from all the tech websites such as CNET, Techradar, Android Central, etc. This would be a great tablet for a teenager because you wouldn't have $600 in an iPad for them to break it or loose it. You can also encrypt the tablet to protect your data if you have sensitive work information. I would recommend this to anyone without hesitation.

Reviews.Title: Bad hardware quality
Reviews.Author: Erick Houli
Reviews.Content: I've had the tablet for a few weeks and found out today that the Microphone is not working, after Googling (isn't it ironic?) these Nexus 7 have been known to have this issue, I bought it through Amazon marketplace, but can't return it because of Adorama's policy.Be my guests, google for Nexus 7 microphone's issue.Other than that, I think is a nice offer for the price, but Google needs to raise their manufacturer's requirement standards, the Nexus 7 has been out for a few months and the issues should've been sorted out.

Reviews.Title: Great tablet with issues
Reviews.Author: J. Harley
Reviews.Content: 2/14 Update-----------After not having much luck with my first two Nexus attempts, I tried a disastrous run with the ASUS TF300.  That tablet was far worse.  I was ready to give up on ASUS altogether and wait for the Tab 3 later this month but after realizing I am still basically waiting for Jelly Bean on my Galaxy Tab Plus in vain simply because Samsung left us to twist in the wind, I decided not to wait for the Tab 3 and gave another Nexus a try from a different vendor altogether.  Wow! What a difference getting a good one makes.  I don't know what was wrong with the first two that I tried but this one is MUCH better.  The screen is clearer and the whites are not as dingy or yellow.  So far, there have been no problems for two weeks now and Android has upgraded three times since purchase (Take that Samsung).  I don't want to jinx myself but I finally have a winner Nexus 7.  The reason I won't upgrade my star rating is because ASUS has wildly inconsistent quality control issues.  The first two Nexus 7s I tried were awful but they were from the same vendor and had similar serial numbers.  The third was from a different vendor and has totally different numbers and best of all, works! It shouldn't be that big of a crap shoot to get a decent ASUS tablet.  Out of the three ASUS Nexus 7's and two ASUS TF300's I've tried the past month, these were the results: Nexus 7 number one exchanged due to severe screen flicker, Nexus 7 number two returned for refund due to failure to charge, TF300 number one was exchanged after developing two very noticeable mura spots (looked like two glowing white orbs), and TF300 number two was returned after developing dead pixels the second day.  It also had significant backlight bleeding that I was willing to overlook, but not the dead pixels as well.  Finally, Nexus 7 number three is perfect so far.  Not to toot Apple's horn but facts are facts.  I've purchased five iPads, at least one from every generation, since its initial release and not once have I had such problems with them.  If you can get a good one, the Nexus 7 is a great tablet.  ASUS, please get your Q&A; together.  There is a fine line between value and cheap.  If the quality is that shoddy, may as well buy one of those cheap knock-off tablets.--------------------I recently purchased a 32 GB Nexus 7 to compliment my standard iPad for those times when I don't feel like holding such a hefty device.  First, the form factor is perfect.  It fits perfectly in one hand and I love that there are only two buttons, power and volume. The rear has a bumpy matte plastic finish that makes it easier to hold without it sliding.  I figured with the specs and for $249, it was a steal.  Then I turned it on.  The first thing that disappointed me was how warm the screen color was.  If you have nothing to compare it to, it looks acceptable if not a tad washed out; however, when I placed it next to my wife's Galaxy Tab Plus, it was no contest.  Her tablet was much brighter, more vibrant and displayed much better looking pure whites.  By comparison, my whites looked dingy with a yellowish tint and colors were more washed-out.  Despite less than stellar colors, the 1280X800 display was more sharp and crisp than the Tab.  I noticed that the colors on the Nexus improved a bit after the screen had a little time to burn it, although they were still no match for the Tab, even with the tab's lower resolution.As far as performance, it was a mixed bag.  I have to say I honestly expected better.  For instance, Subway Surfers runs flawlessly on my iPad 3 but stutters at times on my Nexus. Now, I realize the iPad 3 has a better GPU, but the Nexus was only marginally better than the Tab as well.  The Nexus even rebooted spontaneously on me a couple times for no reason during tasks.  That leads me to my biggest problem with the device, too many quirks.  Other than the random reboot, the first Nexus I had was okay.  I was perfectly content to keep it until the screen started randomly flickering.  I first noticed it during gaming but noticed it in other areas as well.  I'd have flashing horizontal lines across the display.  I subsequently exchanged it for another Nexus 7.The second Nexus was much like the first but with noticeably less flicker.  I was actually enjoying it for nearly a week until the battery completely drained during use and I attempted to charge it.  I had previously charged the device once before but the battery wasn't completely drained during that initial charge.  It was down to roughly 2%.  I plugged it up and it charged fine.  This time however, I plugged it up and instead of the charging icon, the unit booted.  I figured it was normal because my iPad and iPhone also boot after charging a few minutes with a completely drained battery.  However, it booted to the main screen, the low battery alert sounded and the device shut down again.  I again mistakenly assumed this was normal and that it just went dark to charge.  However, it rebooted again, and again, and again....  Each time it rebooted, the main screen would display for a few seconds, the low battery alert sounded and it rebooted again.  It seemed like it was getting just enough juice to boot and then shut down, only to repeat the process.  I allowed it to do this for roughly 10 minutes, hoping it would eventually get enough juice to end the cycle and charge normally, but it didn't.  I then scoured the Internet for answers and was shocked by the number of users reporting screen flicker and charging issues.  The weird thing is, although I came across a few random bad reviews of the tablet from users during my research before purchase, I did not encounter the staggering number of reviews specifically related to my same issues until I typed the exact symptoms into the search engine.Needless to say, I followed the advice I found in an Android forum and booted into the boot loader and allowed it to charge a bit in there.  Once I rebooted, it charged normally.  I wanted to see if I could duplicate the issue, so I again allowed the battery to completely drain and attempted to charge.  So far, I am unable to duplicate the issue.  I honestly feel all these issues are tied into the latest Android version 4.2.1.  Many people are content to keep finding solutions as new random problems arise or they are sadly beyond their return period (I saw quite a few posts filled with buyer's remorse) but I don't have time for all that nonsense, so back it went.  Last year I was furious with Samsung for taking forever with their Ice Cream Sandwich updates and that's how my wife ultimately ended up with the Galaxy Tab Plus which was originally mine.  I now see that it's best to hold out until the developer is absolutely certain that the software is ready instead of releasing half-baked updates.  When you have pure Android, you get the most recent updates faster than anyone else but you also get all of the early adopter issues that go along with it.  In any event, I returned the second Nexus 7 and won't be trying a third.  I was tempted to exchange it for a Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 Plus, but I understand the Tab 3 is rumored to be just around the corner.  So I'm going to wait it out for now and stick to the big old iPad.  I'm honestly not interested in the Mini at the current price and prefer a small Android tablet.The Nexus 7 is a promising and very capable small tablet.  I personally know several people who own it and have experienced no problems.  Maybe I'm either unlucky or too picky but I don't want to keep rolling the dice and hoping to finally get a unit without issues.  Without the flakiness, I'd probably rate it four stars, with the one star being knocked off for the poorly calibrated display.  However, taking my issues with two separate tablets into account, I rated it as highly as I feel it deserves based on my personal experience.  Depending on the release date for the Nexus 7 second generation, maybe I'll see if I have better luck with that model. That is assuming I don't have a Galaxy Tab 3 7.0 by then.

Reviews.Title: Stay Away
Reviews.Author: badger1
Reviews.Content: After four months of use, battery life is abysmal. Loses 70% of battery while in sleep mode, OVERNIGHT! Device almost unusable as a result. Apparently a defect in the product (based on the number of users complaining of the same thing) but Google does nothing to support it. I won't buy another Google-branded product again, and I suggest you avoid doing so also.

Reviews.Title: Turned into a brick in less than a month. No customer service.
Reviews.Author: Sean G Cook
Reviews.Content: Under all circumstances, avoid ASUS products. I bought a Google Nexus 7. It turned into a brick within a month. My friend bought one as well, which also turned into a brick shortly after. Both had screen issues and would not power on properly.After Googling, I found this problem was very common.You would think a company like ASUS would handle this responsibly, but rather than acknowledge their s***ty product they treat each case as some sort or random one off, make customers go through a difficult process only to get the run around over and over.I have given up and accepted that I threw away 250 dollars by trusting ASUS as a company. Stay away from anything manufactured by them. Tell your friends to stay away. There are enough options out there that you can find a company that builds decent products and has decent customer service.To quote another review I agree with 100%:"This company gladly will sell you anything but the first time it breaks you will get NO customer service what so ever. And they will do everything they can to avoid honoring the warranty."

Reviews.Title: owned mine for a year and a half, great all around device.
Reviews.Author: Tom  Lisa
Reviews.Content: It will stream 1080p youtube no problem. Supports OTG (usb host), I have used usb: keyboards, mice, hubs, USB to serial adapters.

Reviews.Title: Glad I got one of these!
Reviews.Author: cory-Carnifex
Reviews.Content: For the money I'd have to say this thing is top notch. It's powerful, smooth, fast and easy to use. I have a Samsung galaxy S4 now but before I had the DROID RAZR and this tablet works a lot like that. It has more ram than the RAZR but the same amount of memory. There are some apps that don't work for the tablet that worked on my phone but they aren't critical things. I enjoy typing on the 7" display as well. One other thing that got me to buy this is that it is something T-mobile carries and as I go europe a lot with my band having the option to pay for a month if service so I can keep in touch with my girlfriend and father while I'm there. Internet isn't always an option or it doesn't work. T-mobile is a Germany based company so keeping in touch is easy. This things runs games well and has decent battery life. I only gave it 4 stars because the screen is pretty white heavy and not very color rich. The nexus 7 2nd gen has a much better resolution.

Reviews.Title: Great product!
Reviews.Author: Shereen
Reviews.Content: Google products always seem to run the smoothest and look overall appealing. The tablet works great! I would definitely recommend the Google Nexus 7.

Reviews.Title: Working fine
Reviews.Author: Leo
Reviews.Content: Plenty of storage space and fast viewing pictures and videos.Has a great screen for reading too.Tested with some games and had no problem.

Reviews.Title: Great tablet!
Reviews.Author: tigerlily
Reviews.Content: I got this as a gift for my daughter. She absolutely loves it & it works great! It's easy to use and has great picture & sound quality. Terrific tablet for the price.

Reviews.Title: Great tablet
Reviews.Author: iceolate "iceolate3k"
Reviews.Content: I wanted one of these for a long time, I use it at work on a daily basis. Great when rooted with a custom ROM!

Reviews.Title: I LOVE IT!!
Reviews.Author: tom
Reviews.Content: This is generation 1 (2012) so know that! I love it cause I use it for notes, books, bible app (Youvision), syncing files, light browsing, emails, not really videos but NETFLIX does work! and I downloaded and played BREACH AND CLEAR on it and that operates perfectly fine.great great price for $109.99 and runs perfectly!

Reviews.Title: Fantastic
Reviews.Author: divakar mithal
Reviews.Content: Full disclosure: I returned this item but not because of any deficiency. The circumstances for which I bought it changed, and instead of keeping I returned it.I have used a wide array of touch-screen technologies and tend to favor the Apple environment. I think the samsung tablets are excellent, however, and have considered shifting to them in the past. I think this 7" Nexus tablet was simply fantastic, and with the seamless google integration, was a breeze to set up.Particularly, I found the sim card functionality, minimal-lag scrolling and google apps to be very useful. I had no problems at all. We had a novice adult touch screen user using it within an hour of opening the box.I used a pre-paid sim w/ 3g service and that service was up and running without a hitch.This product is highly recommended. The only downside that I can see is that has a little glare on the screen. A matte screen protector could help with that, but it's not necessary.

Reviews.Title: Excellent
Reviews.Author: Nadine Graham
Reviews.Content: In love with this tablet, so happy i purchase for my personal use. The quality is excellent. Will purchase the keyboard to go with it

Reviews.Title: Awesome! In love with this device!!
Reviews.Author: Cynstrends
Reviews.Content: I absoluely love this device! It is exactly what I was looking for. It has the versatility I needed in a netbook and am thrilled to find something so user friendly and not have to go with an iPad. The size is great, slips conveniently in my purse, so I take it everywhere. The speaker is great. I can set this baby up in my living room, click on my favorite tunes and hear it all over the house. In fact I am considering seriuosly buying a second one.

Reviews.Title: Excellent buy!
Reviews.Author: Latanya R Gathers
Reviews.Content: I love my google Nexus 7!  It is totally what everyone says it is!  Fast, accurate, and so much more!.  The shipping was super fast too. Ordered on fri and package was on doorstep on Monday!  If you don't have this, go out and pick this up! You won't be disappointed!

Reviews.Title: Great deal at $149!
Reviews.Author: kavlito
Reviews.Content: I really needed a replacement tablet due to the nature of my PCTuneUpGuy business, working in the field and taking lots of notes.  I use Evernote for all my client work documentation and I use Android's MobileBiz Pro for billing.  This is the perfect form factor for being mobile, and especially with the Thumb Keyboard 4 app, it's very easy for me to take notes on.I was looking at Samsung Tab 3 7, but the specs on this were better, especially 32GB.  It automatically updated through 2 updates to Android 4.4 Kit Kat.  My only disappointment is that the bluetooth does not connect to my Sony BM10.  Don't know whose fault it is.The thinness, the rubber back, the minimalistic design all work great for me.  I added a Zagg invisibleSHIELD screen protector which works great because it has a rubbery feel to it.  Between the rubberized back of the tablet and the screen protector, it makes it so much easier to handle without it feeling like it is going to slip out of my hands.  I returned a Lenovo Mix 2 10 because it was so slippery and just a disaster waiting to happen.For anybody who needs an inexpensive, quality tablet... Grab em while you can!

Reviews.Title: Absolutely love it
Reviews.Author: Ian Thomas Murphy
Reviews.Content: Nice and lightweight, the battery also lasts a long time which I was pleasantly surprised. I was skeptical about getting a tablet at first but I love this thing, it's great to watch in bed or rest somewhere in the car while parked somewhere.Another thing about this tablet is that it's easy to use and is super responsive and quick, I couldn't really ask for more in a tablet. All in all there isn't anything wrong with this tablet that I can think of, but having a mini HDMI port would make it perfect.

Reviews.Title: great while it lasted
Reviews.Author: d
Reviews.Content: I loved everything about this tablet.  I only had it a month and my son dropped it.  It didn't shatter or crack, but a crucial spot on the screen went unresponsive.I couldn't use it that way, so I went and got a 2nd gen, WiFi only one.  I will say the performance is similar enough between the 1st and 2nd gen that you are totally OK buying the 1st gen. Just don't drop it, mine was in a case and still messed up. :-)

Reviews.Title: Loving it
Reviews.Author: cbob
Reviews.Content: Got hooked up with carrier for the 4g capabilities.  Does great.  Super fast.  Still trying to learn how to take full advantage of all the features.  But, I think it will work out.

Reviews.Title: Sure like this tablet
Reviews.Author: Robert L Burkey
Reviews.Content: This tablet is very nice.  It has all the things I want/need to do.  I would recommend this Nexus 7 to anyone lookig for a full funtion tablet.

Reviews.Title: Very nice.
Reviews.Author: Sharon A. Schalow
Reviews.Content: It has been a lot of fun. It is perfect for what I wanted it for. Gets a little warm, but not to bad. .

Reviews.Title: Its perfect
Reviews.Author: marc heys
Reviews.Content: This version of the Nexus might be 2 years old, but it runs and keeps up with all but the fastest Android devices out currently. Plus I had it rooted and running Cyanogenmod within and hour of opening the box. A huge perk of owning a nexus device.

Reviews.Title: that is the tablet to buy
Reviews.Author: Halil Kukner
Reviews.Content: now there is 2013 model of nexus 7, hence 2012 model was cheaper. we were between 2013 and 2012 models, but then just bought the 2012 model. it is totally awesome & satisfactory  after our smartphones. these tablet are optimized by google chrome provides you a smooth surfing & facebook experience. Moreover, screen quality is really good. images, videos, etc...sound qualtiy is good, too.only thing is there is one front cam, but there isn't any back cam.but of course, tablets are not for photo shooting purpose. since we carry our camera and smartphones with as, this is totally not an issue to mention.the cpu performance is reallly cool. you can open pdf, excel, etc... you can watch HD videos, play games.I am really happy and glad for buying this nexus 7. especially 2012 model is way cheaper than 2013 version.

Reviews.Title: For primary use as GPS/Video Screen
Reviews.Author: APN
Reviews.Content: This is an awesome portable device. I got this during the thanksgiving sale and its going strong even now after continuous use as a GPS for my car [with Copilot offline maps]. The screen isn't as bright and clear as an iPad but it serves the purpose. The speakers are optimal with no high performance features. The graphics is a bit laggy when you scroll fast through web pages or when you start playing Asphalt 8. But when i'm driving with GPS on or listening to music or when i'm streaming HD content through Netflix this tablet performs flawlessly. Its a bit battery hungry when you use GPS but this can be avoided by having an in-car charger for the nexus. Overall for a hundred bucks this is a very worthwhile tablet for outdoor carefree use!

Reviews.Title: excelent  buy
Reviews.Author: RONNY REYES
Reviews.Content: This has been the best buy for my boy 05-year-old gamer. I can now have my laptop back! We have no complaints

Reviews.Title: Best buy
Reviews.Author: Elizabeth J Morefield
Reviews.Content: This has been the best buy for my 11-year-old gamer. I can now have my laptop back! We have no complaints.

Reviews.Title: Great buy
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I love this tablet. My son has one and he convinced me to get one and I am so glad I did. It does everything I need it to and more.

Reviews.Title: lOvE IT!!!!
Reviews.Author: Renai Breisinger
Reviews.Content: Love love love this tablet!!!  So worth the money!  I kept buying cheaper tablets and would only last a week or two!  This tablet was about mid scale and works just as well as my kindle. Very comparable to the kindle!

Reviews.Title: Pleased
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
