I'm biassed towards everything non-Apple and I will happily compare it to an iPad, because people need to know that the extra edge you get on those over-priced Apple products, you don't miss it once you go Android...so therefore what's the real plus of buying into the i-hype?K, enough about Apple: the Nexus I got is a 32GB, seriously could not conceive of getting less storage but now that I know it is expandable using the media importer app, I will be trying that out- on to things I love:1) Capacity (using a small low cost cable) to connect either a keyboard or a mouse or anything that has a usb connection basically...not that I've tried to connect much else than the keyboard or mouse. Anyone who's typed on a tablet knows it's a pain if you want to type a lot of words, so being able to connect a real keyboard is an amazing plus. ASUS why did you not do this with the EEE Pad?2) It's a much more manageable size so portability is great compared to my EEE pad. I can take it almost anywhere without adding too much to my load.3) Has almost everything I had on the ASUS EEE pad, in terms of apps that it came with, and the rest you can DL from the Google Play store, so that's great.4) Long tapping for a paste button seems easy here compared to my EEEpad5) Transfer of files via the usb cable works great, and the files can be read even when the message pops up that they may not be readable. I can watch mp4, avi; read pdfs, txts etc6) The "Play" music app works great, possibly better than it seemed to in my EEE pad...but of course it would be great if I could figure out how to import playlists instead of having to re-create them.7) Bluetooth - so I can connect and pair and share among other devices with Bluetooth, also possibly connect a headset, but haven't tried that yet - gold!Dislikes:1) Has no pre-installed library app...i checked and double-checked...some people mention this elsewhere online, but this is one of the first things I looked for because I loved "MyLibrary" on my EEEpad and have tried to find it for other tablets but it's apparently exclusive to ASUS - and specifically to the EEE pad, because they neglected to put it on my Nexus and it's not available to download. Why?!! It's an ASUS app, Nexus is an ASUS product!! If not for Aldiko, (the free version) and Moon Books, I don't know what I'd do...see now I have to use two apps to do the job that one app did for me previously on the EEE pad, and that is a major fail, imo!2) When I first got it, it seemed to overdo the backspace button action a bit, whenever I clicked one two many times, I'd end up deleting everything I typed without hope of retrieving it...it doesn't seem to do this much anymore, thankfully, but it was a serious flaw in the beginning.3) As mentioned before - there is no micro sd slot (this to me is a no-no) - what's so difficult about including one of those? It's good that there is an option to expand via the usb import cable, but would have been nicer to have it built into the device.4) How do I connect to my TV...? No visible way I can see...no other output ports. If someone can tell me how this will work...like the hdmi output on the EEE pad, that would be great.5) (Added July 2013) I downloaded the Nexus Media Importer app for $3.99 and tried to use it immediately, but it told me something about my license not being recognised. This lasted the first few times but I eventually got it to work. If you ask me, I think they should make the media importer freely available, and if need be, ASUS should subsidise it, because it is their fault there is no way to import media or expand the memory.Note to ASUS: I am getting into the Samsung tablets now, and I will have no compunction in calling a spade a spade...if the Samsung outperforms Nexus, then it will be my new favorite tablet and that Nexus will be the last ASUS product I purchase.Feb 2014 update:The tablet is really starting to have more "incidents" where I have to stick a pin in what I think is a reset "orifice" ...really not sure...never looked at the documentation to see if there was a reset thingy...but anyway, the tablet didn't come on for two whole days until I stuck the pin there...so I guess that must be it...It also is running out of memory after 14 months...I tend to download things I like so I can watch on my tablet...so now I have to remove some of my stuff to external media and use the media importer app more often....

Reviews.Title: powerful android tablet
Reviews.Author: Shimon Harel
Reviews.Content: I love the Nexus 7, I find it exactly the right size, very comfortable to hold in your hand, it's performance is excellent,very fast response, the screen is great to read from (not like a dedicated reader, but very sharp) it's light weight makes it easy to handle without a table and it's Android, what more do you want?

Reviews.Title: Best tablet ever
Reviews.Author: HerbstFam "HerbstFam"
Reviews.Content: Get it. That simple. Nothing bad about it. A+. You will not regret the purchase of this. Great product to buy.

Reviews.Title: My husband loves it
Reviews.Author: Naomi Marble
Reviews.Content: Perfect! Gave to my husband for christmas and he has not put it down since.  He travels a lot and carrying this lightweight tablet is much better than having to drag around his laptop. Would definetly recommend this tablet

Reviews.Title: The Asus Nexus 7 1B32 rocks
Reviews.Author: Anantilio
Reviews.Content: It was an excellente experience to buy it. The best product including Google software and Asus hardware. 2 gb Ram and 32 Gb flash memory. Quad Core and 4.1. Android. All the Google Maps and GPS navigation. And all of this for a very nice price.

Reviews.Title: Asus nexus 7
Reviews.Author: V. Kosey
Reviews.Content: Great tablet, great price.  Fast. Good video.  Great size.  Very glad i decided on this one.  I also have an original ipad so i didn't want to pay so much for a mini.  Perfect for reading, surfing and playing.

Reviews.Title: A great device for a good price.
Reviews.Author: Ricardo Spring
Reviews.Content: This product surely deserves 4 stars. It's pretty well made, starting from it's design and it's hardware. The nexus 7 has already the latest android version (jelly bean) and it's running fine. There are many good points on the Nexus 7: the first one is the battery life that lasts up to 10 hours of continuous using. The second one is that games run pretty smooth on this device, even the newest ones. The downside is probably the absence of a HDMI port. I was planning to connect my nexus to my tv, so i could watch movies bought from google play, but this sounds to be impossible. I recommend this tablet to anyone who need such a device on a regular basis, it's size is also a good advantage, since you are albe to take it anywhere and hold it with only one hand.

Reviews.Title: best tablet for the money
Reviews.Author: steve papesh
Reviews.Content: this being my first android anything, i was aware of a learning curve, but i am very happy i went with this tablet.  works perfectly.

Reviews.Title: my best ever birthday present
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: It does everything I want it to.  My special apps are the Sky Map and Sasol birds.  Being able to download emails whilst travelling is a great bonus

Reviews.Title: Asus Nexus 7 1B32 7-Inch 32 GB Tablet
Reviews.Author: Chris V.
Reviews.Content: Great product! Affordable and performs amazingly!Would definitely buy again and recommend to friends! Worth the money! I love my tablet!

Reviews.Title: So far, I love it!
Reviews.Author: Charlene Hairston
Reviews.Content: Selected this item based primarily on limited research and recommendations from trusted "techy friends." I hope to love the Asus Nexus 7 Tablet for a very long time.

Reviews.Title: Comparison of our two tablets after 6+ months of use
Reviews.Author: Ali Julia

logTag.type = "text/javascript"; logTag.src = "/gp/customer-media/du/log.html?ie=UTF8&p=CustomerImage&s=CustomerVideoPlay"; head[0].appendChild(logTag); } if (cv_mo1GXHQXYGXB0AQcurrentClick) { return cv_mo1GXHQXYGXB0AQcurrentClick(); } } } Length:: 0:05 MinsWe owned Nexus 7 since July 2012 (6 months as of writing this review). We had no technical problems of any sort. Google maps awareness feature is very good, it keeps track of our interest and GPS location and it takes entering only a few characters for perfectly relevant search results to be displayed. Jelly Bean improved voice recognition to a level where we now always talk to the tablet rather than type. Auto updates are terrific, it it nice not to be dependent on the cell phone carrier.This is our second Android tablet. We also bought a Samsung Galaxy 7.7 tablet a few months before Nexus 7 became available. In this review I will compare the features of these two tablets.The big difference between the two tablets is that Nexus 7 always runs the latest version of the operating system. This is because Google is pushing out regular updates. My Galaxy is still on HoneyComb 3.4. I purchased it through Verizon and they are slow with the OS updates. Why does it matter? (1) Some new features available in Jelly Bean OS are really nice (such as improved voice recognition and Google maps awareness features) (2) Eventually more and more applications will not be compatible with the old OS.Nexus 7 does not have a cellular capability. Galaxy 7.7 has this capability, but we did not purchase a data plan. Instead we use the cell phone as a hot spot if there is no WI FI available. The only time this was an issue was when we traveled internationally without having an International cell plan. Outside US we managed by hovering near venues that had free WI FI.The size of the device was one of the major considerations when we were shopping for both tablets. I wanted to have a tablet that would fit into my purse, so I can have it with me anywhere without carrying another item. My husband wanted a tablet he can stick into his pockets (pants or jacket). 7.7 inches works well in my purse, but does not fit his pants pockets. 7 inch Nexus, however, in its neoprene sleeve is a perfect fit for the pockets. I am attaching a collage of 3 photos. Photo #3 shows Nexus 7 going into a pocket.7 inches is also just the right size to use in the car as GPS. It has a bigger screen that our Garmin so it is easier to see the map. My 7.7" tablet is a bit too big to use as GPS as it covers a more of the windshield and creates a bit of visibility issue. To navigate we use either Google Maps or Sygic. The reason we use both is that Google Maps requires a WI FI connection and in some rural areas of Vermont and Maine where we often travel there are areas with bad cell coverage. Sygic, however, works from its own maps and does not require a WI FI connection. See photo #1 shows Nexus 7 running Sygic navigation as we drive.The speaker on Nexus 7 is not very good. We notice this particularly when we began using it as GPS as we could barely hear it. However purchasing a blue tooth speaker solved this problem beautifully. The sounds now is loud and clear.Nexus 7 has no Micro-SD slot (by comparison Galaxy 7.7 Tab does have a Micro-SD slot). However, we resolved this issue by attaching a USB flash drive to Nexus by purchasing Nexus Media Importer app (which currently costs $2.99).I like that I am able to purchase apps from different sources such as Google Market place as well as Amazon. If I want to dable in writing my own mobile apps, I can do so using my own PC and free Eclipse platform with free Android development plug-ins (either under Windows or Linux) without any extra investment. If I wanted to develop apps for iPad I would need to buy a Mac, since I don't own one already.Google's Jelly Bean really improved voice recognition for searches. Under Honey Comb and ICS the search results sometimes were hilarious, especially if tried searching on foreign names, but update Jelly Bean made a significant improvements in voice recognition and now my husband only talk to his tablet. It gets it right 99% of the time on the first try.Nexus 7 has a front facing camera, Samsung Galaxy has two cameras (front and rear facing). None of the cameras are as good as our other cameras, so we don't use them much.Galaxy's AMOLED display is brighter and more brilliant than Nexus. Neither one of us sees any difference in sharpness of text. The higher contrast does make Galaxy screen easier to read in the sun. However, Galaxy 7.7 cost was almost three times as much Nexus 7. Is the screen three times better? No.We use both tablets on daily basis. I listed pluses and minuses for both. For me the most significant difference comes down to the lack of timely OS updates for Galaxy 7.7. So if I had a do-over I would go with two Nexus 7 devices. Nexus 7 has been reliable, helpful, and fun to have.Ali Julia review

Reviews.Title: love my nexus!!!
Reviews.Author: Amy
Reviews.Content: I wish I had gotten this sooner! I love everything it does, except not having a rear camera. I love to read so I hooked up with our public library and download books consistently.  I've downloaded a few games (not much of a gamer) but they look and work great on it.

Reviews.Title: Perfect tablet
Reviews.Author: Dana
Reviews.Content: It is currently the most powerful/up-to-date 7-inch tablet on the market. Nice size runs everything on Google Play fine. Had no problems with the device. I highly recommend and I am ready for the next Google tablet.

Reviews.Title: Leaves all other tablets behind with it's quad core
Reviews.Author: David Salverson
Reviews.Content: I've had other tablets the second I picked up my Nexus 7 with 32 g I was amazed at how fast it is.You can't do anything the tablet won't keep up with.Friends of mine have iPad and iPad mini's they could not believe how much faster my Nexus 7 is.If this is an example of Asus I'm going to look at there laptops when I need a new one.The quality is amazing and the tablet has a very solid feel.I even hook it up to my back up drives with the cable I bought at Amazon.

Reviews.Title: Love it
Reviews.Author: blacktip
Reviews.Content: I bought my wife an Amazon Kindle Fire HD and I have the Nexus 7.  In all, the Nexus 7 beats out the Kindle on all fronts.  I thought the proprietary nature of Apple was bad, that was until I got a hold of my wife's Kindle.  I'll just say, Nexus 7 > Kindle Fire HD.

Reviews.Title: speedy, great battery life
Reviews.Author: Jessica Hall "Jessica"
Reviews.Content: I bought this tablet (32GB) in November to replace a rooted Nook Color and I couldn't be more pleased with that decision. The display is sharp, the processor(s) is fast, and the battery life is wonderful. I can easily get 2 days out of it with light usage, one day with medium usage. Actually, it's currently sleeping with about 48% battery and I haven't charged it in two days. I love that I'm not boxed in with a manufacturer's version of Android -- I get the vanilla Android as Google intended it. I also am not boxed in my only being able to read Kindle or Nook books. I can read either, since I've installed both apps on my tablet. It sits nicely in one hand while I'm reading and has a small enough screen that reading isn't a pain (I didn't want a 10 inch tablet because i feel the screen is way too large). If you're shopping for a "deal" on the Nexus 7, you won't find one -- Google is pretty much selling these babies at cost -- but the Amazon price definitely isn't the best. They want you to buy their Kindle Fire HD. I found mine at Office Depot and was able to walk out of the store with it.

Reviews.Title: Just what the Son wanted!
Reviews.Author: Frank
Reviews.Content: He's in love, likes all the features and the strong battery life, and it's compact size...all the apps, etc.A great gift...

Reviews.Title: nexus 7 32gb version
Reviews.Author: Steven Rovinski "Steve"
Reviews.Content: I purchased this about month a go I'am not a tablet pro. In fact bought it after laptop went down and wasn't sure what new one to get but needed a fill in till i found another one. This tab is great for me. I have since found another laptop but find myself still using the tab most of the time. I really like it. Can't figure how to make calls with it with a app.and it has froze up a couple of times and when you shut it down totally sometimes it dosen.'t want to turn back on.but other than that its great. and yes if your looking for one shop around amazon is not the cheapest place to buy found it 10.00 cheaper at office depot in town.

Reviews.Title: Good product
Reviews.Author: Claudia Cabrera
Reviews.Content: I love it. I bought another one for my 11 years old nephew, works fine and is very intuitive.  I miss a little bit the back camera, but other than that is perfect  for me.

Reviews.Title: Good Product
Reviews.Author: mm
Reviews.Content: This product came well package and is working like a charm. No problems and has nice features Love it alot

Reviews.Title: Great Tablet
Reviews.Author: R. Hennessey
Reviews.Content: I have had this tablet for about a week now it was Xmas present to myself and I just cant put it down and its much betterthan that crappy Coby Kyros tablet I bought about a year ago..The Google nexus is fast and it loads quickly and efficientlyand it streams Netflix without any buffering or stopping and the HBO go app is the best and the Google Play store has tons of appsto chose from...I highly recommend Buying the Google Nexus.

Reviews.Title: Christmas Present
Reviews.Author: Mallory Hall
Reviews.Content: Seems a little more complicated than the iPhone was to start up. I am super excited. We will see how this stands up to its name.

Reviews.Title: Google nexus7 32GB , 4G
Reviews.Author: RAZA ISHAQ BABAR
Reviews.Content: Best 7 inch tab in market, a really smart buy, easy to use and handle, best value for money...take it anywhere size !!

Reviews.Title: Not recommended
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I wish I had a more positive review to write.  I loved this tablet for the first month that I had it.  Great...everything I was looking for in a tablet.  Until it just stopped working one day, wouldn't even turn on beyond the flashing "X".  I had to send it back to Asus (and pay $15 to ship it back).  They had it for 3 weeks, fixed whatever it was and everything was going well.  I thought, "Oh good, that's done with".  Had it for another couple of weeks and then it stopped charging.  Even when it was plugged in and not begin used, it would continue to lose juice.  So, I sent it back again.  To make matters worse, Asus wanted me to pay for shipping again, but I refused so they agreed to pay. I've heard of others having similar issues.  I envy those that haven't, but from what I've experienced, I wouldn't recommend this product to ANYONE!  What a disappointment.

Reviews.Title: Bricked straight out of the box (black screen of death) Basically a $280 cutting board.
Reviews.Author: Dennison Armando
Reviews.Content: Apparently many people are having issues with the Nexus 7 and the infamous "black screen of death." I did not know that this was a major issue affecting many people and therefore was pretty shocked (through browsing forums, reading reviews, ect.) that this was an issue affecting many customers. Normally, customers would be able to at least turn the device on and use it for several days before everything went straight to hell. This was not what happened with my product.As much as I love the fact that with the Nexus 7, you get the MOST bang for your buck, such issues are rather unacceptable for such a great product. Considering the price is relatively steep (upwards of 280$), this product should not be having such issues. In terms of the fixes I have seen on the internet, a few have mentioned holding the power button for approximately 30 seconds, attempting to enter into cold-boot menu, ect... In the case of my product, I plugged the item into an AC adaptor and saw the screen flicker on. Afterwards, the screen remained black. At first, I thought this was normal and would take some time... About 25 minutes later, I eventually concluded that the item was indeed defective... The item would not even enter cold-boot as I held down the power button and volume buttons.All in all, I'm terribly disappointed with this buy and would not recommend purchasing this product online or at all even. The risk is simply not worth having your device instantly bricked. Right now, my item is better off as a $280 cutting board.

Reviews.Title: A nightmare and hopeless despair with this Nexus 7
Reviews.Author: O. yips chou "the turtle student"
Reviews.Content: I bought this product in Pricesmart in January, initially it was doing well despite that is has some quirk with the operating system.Then in March 27, the tablet automatically downloaded android 4.22 and installed it, then the problems begin. Several important programs like Facebook, Google Play do not work. It exit immediately when run. So, I did a factory reset. The problem with the reset is that it will not reset to anything, it just keep saying 'Unfortunately the setup wizard has stopped.'So I wanted to return to Pricesmart, but the manager says that Pricesmart is not responsible o there is no warranty if you update the operating system, they cannot receive it or refund it.So I guess that this product is useless. Spent $300 for the cost for two months, that is stupid and silly. Just throw it to the trash can.Don't buy Google Nexus!----------------------------------------------------------------------What happened to the tablet after all ?For the curiosity of the readers, I took it to a private tech repair shop. After several days checking the tablet, he called me that the repair cost, beside software failure, there is also a hardware failure, will be more than $300 dollars. So it will be more expensive than buying a new one. So I decided not to repair and threw the tablet to the trash can! Really!

Reviews.Title: An Absolute Nightmare
Reviews.Author: Michael Evans
Reviews.Content: I am taking a trip to Israel in March and I decided to purchase a tablet computer for e-book reading, video watching, some games and music, as well as using wi-fi to stay in contact with my wife and son at home. I have an Apple iPod Touch at the moment, and while I was pleased with the product, I decided that the iPads were a little too pricey for what they offer, and were mostly marketed based on the name. It was then that I stumbled upon the Google Nexus. I've always been impressed with the good name of Google and the services they provide and after reading several good reviews I decided to go with the Nexus.I can safely say that I was very impressed with the product. For the first three months I loaded up some apps from the Play store, copied over some videos and music and basically used it as my primary computer, including contacts and calendar. I stored lots of photos and other documents and carried it around all the time.Then, a few days ago, after shutting it off it would not boot. It would constantly stay on the "X" logo and never go past that. I tried resetting it many times, searched the forums for answers and then called Google. After some diagnostics over the phone they told me that there was nothing they could do and to call ASUS. I then called ASUS, and after an hour of pressing this button and that they told me we needed to do a factory reset and wipe the device. I shuddered and agreed and then went ahead. After wiping the device completely clean of everything I had on it, restoring it to factory settings, we tried to reboot it and the same thing occurred. It would get to the "X" and go no further.The telephone support then told me I needed to package up the device and send it in to be repaired which will take roughly three weeks, IF they have the parts. So after spending over an hour packaging the device, taking it to the post office and having it shipped out, here I sit without a tablet.At this point, only three months after purchasing the device, I have now lost all of my data, spent  over $300 + shipping costs (which I had to pay) and have nothing to show for it. Also, having spent 2.5 hours on the phone and another hour packaging and shipping the device, not to mention the time I spent trying to boot it back up myself. The best case scenario now is that they can somehow fix the device and send it back, basically a refurb, and then hope that it will work correctly and is worth going back and reinstalling all of my apps and data from the beginning.Before this experience I always viewed Google as a quality company and I highly recommended the Nexus to my friends and family. In light of this experience I am not impressed. I will consider this my last purchase of any kind with the name Google or Asus, and the first of many complaints to my friends and family of the poor quality of Google products, and its services.

Reviews.Title: DOA Seems Common Problem
Reviews.Author: Robin
Reviews.Content: Ordered the 32GB Nexus 7 for a Christmas present for the wife. Would not take a charge and would only boot twice while the charger was connected. Seems to be a common problem with the Nexus 7. Reading other reviews, identical issue. Returned to vendor but they seem not even trying to replace and just issued a refund. Perhaps they know something. A previous query to ASUS on this problem got nothing but deafening silence. Contacting Google got a sympathetic autoresponder. Getting my money back and being away from the Nexus 7 is probably a good thing.

Reviews.Title: Amazing out of the box, then  :(
Reviews.Author: r0b
Reviews.Content: I followed the quick start instructions, charged up the device, read the manual, then powered up the device. It was working great, I loaded it up with apps, brought it in my truck, and plugged it in to my usb charger, no problems there. I plugged it in at home, it recognized that it was charging. the next day, I updated the o.s. as prompted, and then the device only would charge while turned off, and was no longer recognized by my p.c.. I restored to factory settings without the problem being resolved, and now must use dropbox to load local media. It's a great device, just buy it from somewhere local so that exchanges are easy.

Reviews.Title: Awesome tablet, with a couple slight annoyances
Reviews.Author: Brian C. Driver
Reviews.Content: For background - I have had a budget Android tablet and several Android phones for personal use, and I have an iPad and an iPhone for work, and my wife has a Nook Color, so I am well-versed in mobile technology and capability.I've had this tablet for around a month, and overall, I quite like it.  I got it primarily for web-browsing, ebooks (via the Nook app), and games, with some light productivity, mostly around the house.  I had expected to continue to use my mobile to listen to music at home, and to check Facebook and email, since it's "pocketable" and I have it on my most of the time.  As it turns out, the Nexus, while not something I'd take out with me running errands, fits nicely in a front pants pocket, and I find myself using it almost exclusively as my mobile device while I'm at home, for everything but phone calls.Here are the details:Pros:*The screen is amazing - very crisp, with deep blacks, great viewing angles, and accurate color representation.  Coming from a Super AMOLED screen on my phone, I was a bit worried, since this is a basic ISP panel, but it's awesome.  Touch response is quick and accurate as well.*Super-quick quad-core CPU - this had taken almost everything I've thrown at it with little slowdown.  Oddly, Facebook sometimes gives it pause, but most people I know have some problems with the Facebook mobile app.  Installs apps super-quick after downloading, and loads them up quickly as well.*Smooth, fast graphics - I can't believe how good the graphics are getting on tablets these days.  No complaints - 3d games play smoothly, with very little lag or stuttering.*Super-quick Wifi - I have a 25Mbps Fios connection, and this tablet maxes it out, even over wifi-G.  Downloaded a 1.3 GB game in a few minutes.*Jelly Bean 4.2 interface - Smooth animations, and I love the widgets available.*Swype-like keyboard in 4.2 (you might have to upgrade out of the box) - I got hooked on Swype on my Samsung GS II phone, but was worried about how it would work on a tablet with the larger screen.  While the keyboard isn't actually Swype, but rather an Android-stock knock-off, it works very well. Only complaint is that the function to add words to the dictionary after manually spelling them out is not always available.*Media - video playback is superb, due to the great screen, and the sound is decent-ish without headphones.  Plug headphones in, and the sound is great - not distorted, with decent dynamic range.  Netflix works great, as does Youtube, Vimeo, and other streaming apps.*Form factor/feel - despite minor issues with build quality I touch on below, this is pleasant to hold.  Enough heft you know it's not a cheaply made device, but not too heavy, with a nicely textured rubber back.  The closest thing I can compare it to is the Nook Color - the rubberized back makes both devices easy to hold, although this has a glass bezel, so it gets thumbprints easily.  No worries - the glass cleans nicely with a cloth, or in a pinch, the tail of a t-shirt.*Battery life - lasts from morning to night, while checking email, web, Facebook, etc., watching Youtube videos, and playing lots of games (usually Angry Birds or Minecraft).  Easily lasts 12 hours of light-to-medium intermittent use throughout the day.*Standard Micro-USB port - THANK YOU!  So many tablets these days use proprietary charging/data ports, so this was very refreshing, and since I have several high-current USB chargers, I'm not lacking for places to plug this thing in, when the battery finally does die.Cons*Build quality - as I mentioned above, there are a couple minor issues.  For one, there's a plastic trim ring running around the device, that has a bit of flex in it.  And due to this, it appears the glass on the left side (viewing it in portrait mode) is pushed up a bit.  This is only an illusion - the plastic trim ring has warped a bit, so that the edge of the glass is exposed by a hair's breadth, where on the other sides of the device, the plastic trim is raised above the glass ever-so-slightly.  If I'd spent $500 on this, I might have returned it, but it's acceptable given the price.  Although I do hope Google/ASUS do change this bit of the design on future revisions, as I've read about it in other reviews.  This is what I docked the star off for.*No SD card - worth noting, but since I knew this going in, I didn't dock a star.  I know Google/ASUS wanted to charge a premium for extra storage, but come on - microSD ports wouldn't have added a lot of cost, and wouldn't have required much space.  This was a very Apple thing to do.  That said, 32GB is a lot of storage, and with so many cloud services supported, I mainly only need the local storage for games and to sync Google data.Some apps I'd recommend:Spotify - the best streaming music service I've tried, the app works great on this tabletGrand Theft Auto Vice City - if you liked the original, it will be a blast form the pastMinecraft PE - Minecraft, on a tabletAngry Birds Star Wars - best Angry Birds game so far, IMOGoogle Drive - If it's not already installed (can't remember) get it - this is a great little content creation tabletNook for Android - great reading app, and it works with ePub format, unlike the *other* ebook vendor's reading app (cough, cough)Marvel Comic reader - I'm not a huge comic fan, but after reading a couple free issues, this is the way comics should be readUnified Remote - great remote app to control your PC, with mouse and keyboard capability, it's an awesome app for anyone with a home theater PC who doesn't want to drag out a full-size keyboard.  Get the free version for basic mouse/keyboard/media capability, get the full version for several dozen apps, including every flavor of media player/center, file broswers, power, etc.  My favorite Android app hands down.Advanced Task Killer - lets you easily and quickly shut down background apps, either from a menu, or with a one-touch widgetES File Explorer - easily navigate local storage, and also browse UPnP networked storage.  I use this to pull down movies off my server.

Reviews.Title: Best Bang for your Buck
Reviews.Author: Dragember
Reviews.Content: I'll be honest, I never saw myself owning a tablet, but honestly I felt this one was a bit too good to pass up.Pros:- Cheap! If your not buying off of Amazon, you can find this tablet at $230.00. It's one of the cheapest on the market.- 7 inch display- Gripable back- High resolution screen- Very fast- Runs Jellybean 4.2 (comes with 4.1)- Updates now allow for keyboard swiping- Compact, able to hold in one hand- Good button Locations (on/off and volume are located at the side)- No crashes, can handle multiple apps running at once- Little to no heating, even when extremely active- Great Battery life- None slip air pockets on back- Google now, Sbeam, and other awesome features- HTML Browser- Has 32GB of Flash Memory- Has 720p video (comes with a quality cap that you can break with an app to get the full potential.)- Has 1 GB of RAM- Has GPS- Has Blutooth- Weight is .7 lbs and is well distributed- Scratch Proof Corning® Fit GlassCons:- Auto correct is sometimes dumb.- No USB port- No SIM Slot- Poor speakers- No back facing camera- front facing camera has poor quality (1.2 MP). The Video is 720P, haven't tested it yet.- No Flash Support- No Radio (can stream online radio)- No GPRS (Cannot connect to 4G, 3G networks, though there is a Nexus that can)- No EDGENow something I love about this tablet is the screen resolution. 1280x800, it has better image quality than the iPad Mini. The Nexus 7 has 216 ppi compared to the iPad Mini's 163 ppi, overall the Nexus 7 has a higher density pixel display. My uncle, who works for Microsoft is envious of it's quality display when compared to his iPad Mini (he hates Microsoft products). The display has a contrast ratio of 908:1, which is very excellent. It's really too bad that there aren't amazing speakers to go with this amazing display, and that's the devices's greatest failure in my opinion.The speakers are soft spoken, and when raised too high emit some weak strained audio. They work, they get the job done, but when it comes to watching some Netflix in bed, I get out the headphones. Otherwise they're okay for the on the spot you tubing and what not, they just could be better is all. Here are the stats on decibels:Loudspeaker Voice 68dB / Noise 65dB / Ring 75dBAudio quality Noise -69.8dB / Crosstalk -72.1dBThe keyboard is pretty intelligent and smooth. There have been updates since it's release and one of them included the swipe keyboard. It works really well. My only complaint is that occasionally it auto corrects something oddly, but that's not something an update could easily solve.Now for me the camera wasn't a very big deal, it's primary purpose I assume would be for skyping. If I'm planning on a skype session, I would probably bring the laptop out. So I don't think I'm ever going to really need the camera. The camera genuinely sucks though, it's pixally and could have been a lot better. Still, I suppose when Google made it, they weren't really intending the user to take high quality photos with their tablet. I'll give them leniency here, since it's a fairly useless feature on a tablet anyways.The Nexus 7 runs on 1GB of ram, and has a Tegra 3 Quad-core processor. Basically it runs very fast. It has yet to freeze up on me, not counting when a crappy app crashes. It can run multiple apps with breeze and smoothly transition through them. Apps load very quickly, as do webpages. Boot up is a matter of a second or so. I love how the unit doesn't overheat, ever.There are two very large copper heat sinks that surround the tablet that give it this ability. I've used this tablet throughout the entire day with multiple apps open, streaming videos, playing games, and it only gives off a mild warmth.The system software itself is amazing. Jellybean works splendidly and is indeed very buttery. Transitions through apps are very graceful and pleasing to the eye. I personally like the color layout the system has (black and a particular blue text). The navigation is very easy to figure out and the tablet is very easy to use. There are a lot of system adjustments you can do, and my personal favorite feature is the message for the lock screen. I have an if found message, being the forgetful person I am I thought this was a nice touch since I don't want to sharpey my name on the device. One of the greatest featues of Android, in my opinion, is the ability to customize your device. There's a nice array of widgets out there, that and some neat live wallpaper. Unlike the iPad Mini, one Nexus' display could look vastly different than the next one, while the iPads only differ in background and App choices. The system is very simple and easy to use, very user friendly.When it comes to browsing the web I've heard a few Flash complaints, since it runs HTML. There are several ways to get around this, but I thought I would just mention that no, the Nexus does not come supporting Flash. The Nexus 7 runs an HTML5 browser, and I haven't had any difficulty with it.With 32 GB of space, you have some room to upload your favorite songs and movies, store some pictures. For $230.00, this is a great amount of memory. Honesty, its a steal, have a look at other tablets and their storage vs. Price - price range.The battery is long lasting. One charge lasts throughout the day on heavy use. Using it lightly, it can last well over 100 hours. This thing is very efficient battery wise. The only thing that drains the battery is the GPS for obvious reasons. Streaming movies, I'd estimate it would last around 11 hours. I've read somewhere that this has to due with it's quad core, and it's extra core. This extra core only runs while it's in sleep mode. This alone helps vastly improve battery life, that and the quad core makes the Android overall very efficient.Finally the design of the tablet. For some, the rubber-pastically like back may be unattractive, to me it's a plus. It prevents slippage, and while the iPad Mini's backing looks more attractive, on cold morning I'd be afraid of shattering it on the floor. There are small indentions all over the back of the Nexus for the purpose of creating more friction. It's supposed to allow a firm grip, even if your palms are sweaty. The face of the Nexus looks very sleek, it doesn't gather much smudge and is very simple to clean. I think the silvery lining around the edge of the device adds a nice touch as well. The face of the screen is made with Corning® Fit Glass, which is scratch resistant. I have yet to get a case for the device, but from what I can tell, there aren't even light surface scratches.Also just a quick bit about Corning® Fit Glass, I'm guessing it's a Corning® product. Asus is using Corning® Fit Glass in all of its newly announced products. Earlier Asus stated that they would be using Corning®Gorilla®Glass2 in all of their 2012 products, so I'm not what's really going on. I'm assuming it's a Corning® product because the title is capitalized, "Fit Glass", on all of the product descriptions, other people assume it's just scratch resistant glass that Corning® fitted for Asus. Whatever your take on it, the glass has so far proven resilient for me, so they are probably using the same technique for making the product as they have for Gorilla®Glass, or better.Here's Asus' statement on it: "ASUS TruVivid technology with Corning® Fit Glass for improved color clarity and scratch resistance."Overall I love this tablet. It's certainly the best bang for your buck. It looks like quality, it feels like quality, best of all, it is quality. I enjoy the size, and feel the 7 inch screen is just right. I can hold this tablet comfortably in one hand, and could even fit it inside my pocket. It's the best deal out there when concerning price and quality. Comparing it to my Uncle's iPad Mini, I'd say it can do everything his can do, only cheaper. As for the Kindle Fire, it's nothing compared to a tablet running full Android with access to the Google app store. I've looked through the Amazon App store, there's such limitation on which apps can be used, it puts a limitation on the device itself. Kindle Fire is much too Amazon based for me, and I like the more open ecosystem that Google's Nexus 7 has to offer.*I haven't tried this out for myself, and quite honestly am not certain how to go about it, but the Nexus can run game streaming... Use controllers, ect? It seems very interesting and I'll add an update, as that's potentially an awesome feature.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic Device, Too many complaints,
Reviews.Author: Ben Small
Reviews.Content: If you look online you'll see that there are hundreds of posts on forums about Nexus 7 not charging, etc. After a Year of use, my Nexus 7 died after having it's battery run down and shut off. Ever since then I haven't been able to charge it, even after trying every single solution I could find online, from disconnecting and reconnecting the battery's plugin to trying button combos. This week I decided to get a replacement battery, and after installing it the tablet would boot up like normal but still wouldn't charge. While installing the new battery I noticed that inside the tablet there is enough room for the battery to bump around and get loose, pulling on the plugin for it and making it destroy itself. I'm not the only person with this problem and I think you should rethink your choice because of how often this problem occurs.

Reviews.Title: Dont buy a Nexus7 Tablet
Reviews.Author: TexasLady
Reviews.Content: I have sent my Nexus 7 tablet back 3 times and they have NOT fixed it yet.  The touch screen doesn't work but about 5 seconds then I have to turn it off then back on.  It worked great for awhile then kapot!!! When you call you get Bahamas and then have to send it to Dallas,  I have asked for supervisor before but they always just not available.  Would not even recommend this lousy product to a dog.  The warranty they say comes with it is not worth the time it takes you to hear about it so go look elsewhere for something to spend your money on.

Reviews.Title: Sound??
Reviews.Author: Eimi Berger
Reviews.Content: The specs were nice, it ran fast, it looked good, but the sound was terrible! I could barely hear even in a quiet room, had to return it

Reviews.Title: Nexus Won't Turn On
Reviews.Author: alwaysherway
Reviews.Content: i had this product only seven months.  I bought it in July 2013.  Now it won't turn on and it won't take a charge.A total waste of money!

Reviews.Title: poor quality and customer service
Reviews.Author: Janine Henry
Reviews.Content: I received the Google Nexus 7 tablet as a gift a few months ago. Within days the camera stopped working. I sent back the tablet because it was still under warranty. The camera was replaced and sent back almost a full month later. Upon receiving the "repaired" tablet the volume controls did not work and scrolling became a problem. I called the company who said they would replace the table. Another month later I got my "new" tablet. Unfortunately it had the same serial number as the old tablet. This new tablet as well had malfunctioning volume controls and scrolling. After 2 months of hassle and using a poorly functioning tablet I am requesting a full refund. I now realize I just should have spent the extra money on an ipad...

Reviews.Title: Peice of junk. Excellent Paperweight.
Reviews.Author: Kolton
Reviews.Content: I highly anticipated this Tablet but was extremely disapointed in it. Out of the box it is ok but once it was a bout half full of music and only a few other apps (nothing intensive or ran in the back ground) it got extremely slow to where it almost was unusable. The only fix I could find was to free up storage. For some reason the memory was almost always atleast 75% full and again I have very few apps that run in the background of the ones that do are very light weight. Unfortunately after about 4 months the USB port just stopped working completely (very well taken care of by the way) and would then charge only on the dock. Well about 2 weeks ago it stopped registering the dock and now won't charge at all. Due to the performance of a cheap $50 phone and lasting less than a year before it randomly stopped working I decided it isn't nowhere near worth its price. I will never by a nexus 7 again and may even be on edge with ASUS products as I have plenty of failures with them before.

Reviews.Title: problem
Reviews.Author: teach
Reviews.Content: I can't charge it. Read on google that need strong electricity current and apparently I don't or the battery was a dude.in any case it is useless. I guess I should have returmed

Reviews.Title: Only worked for 5 MONTHS! Sent back to Asus for warranty claim.
Reviews.Author: jim
Reviews.Content: Worked great for 5 months then it would no longer turn on. I called Asus and we couldn't get it started. So this product was returned to Asus for a warranty claim. I am NOT happy forking out $300 where the tablet stops working AFTER ONLY 5 MONTHS OF USE!

Reviews.Title: Superfast, light, amazing definition.  Half the price of ipad mini.
Reviews.Author: Chisti
Reviews.Content: I bought this for a class (my first tablet) and opted for the Nexus 7 rather than ipad mini for various reasons.  The fact that it is half the price of its competitor was certainly a factor, but it was the speed that sold me.  (something like 27 times faster than ipad)  Also, even I, average sized woman, can hold it in one hand.  The quality of the picture is outstanding.  Almost clearer than real life.  Very happy I made this choice.

Reviews.Title: Poor asus tablet, even poorer customer service
Reviews.Author: asusstinks
Reviews.Content: My first review ever and it is a negative one. The nexus 7 ,which I purchased for my parents, started having the common "power down" problem that has been so commonly cited for this tablet with the first few months. The tablet would just power off and not power back up for a few days. Since my parents were in India, we had to call the customer service in India on the one phone number that was provided. And that single phone number did not work. When we contacted the customer service here in US, they said they could do nothing. Promised call backs from supervisors never happened. And the entire customer service team(I spoke to atleast 8) were unhelpful and rude to say the least. Now 6 months after my first report, the tablet doesn't power on at all and we are out of warranty and Asus expects me to pay for repair of this piece of junk. I have been owning an ipad for years now without any issues. I just feel sorry that I wasted my money on a product which shouldn't be out there in the market. Please don't waste your money and time on this worthless product and crappy customer service.

Reviews.Title: Broke after 2 months!
Reviews.Author: techjay
Reviews.Content: Bought this for my wife and we had to reset it at least twice a week. Called Asus tech support and we did a few things they suggested and we still had to reset it. I thought it was just a glitch with the Android OS but was wrong. Now it won't turn on and is going in for warranty.

Reviews.Title: Consider it disposable
Reviews.Author: mon petit chou
Reviews.Content: I'd just like to post a warning to customers about the Nexus 7 because of my bad experience with ASUS not honoring its warranty. Although I was really impressed at first with the general interface and device, I had problems early on with it charging until finally it stopped charging at all. After some online research, I found many other consumers have had problems with their Nexus degrading within months. As of now, ASUS has been holding my tablet hostage after I sent it in weeks ago for repairs, and now accusing me of 'customer-induced damage, waiting for customer confirmation' - which is not at ALL the case, and no one has contacted me. This is after showing a status of 'repair in progress' for weeks so it doesn't make sense how the status became customer-induced after they had been working on it. Every time I call, no one can give me a solid answer to the status and they just keep telling me to wait for 'the email.' I highly warn anyone from purchasing this item from Google, mainly because of it's ASUS partnership. Really disappointed as I've always thought of Google as a reliable company, but should have done my research about ASUS. Otherwise I've always used Mac products and am used to reliable and prompt tech support. I bought this full price - so pretty much $300 down the drain, as well as all of the apps and books I had purchased on that tablet.

Reviews.Title: Pretty good for the money
Reviews.Author: Nycylith
Reviews.Content: Well worth the money. Batterly life is fairly good, and it feels pretty solid. The speeds are good, but my only gripe is the screen color. I am comparing the resolution to my Samsung Galaxy S3 and it doesn't compare in quality hence the missing star, but everything else is great as others have stated.

Reviews.Title: google nexus broken on arrival
Reviews.Author: gary ackerson
Reviews.Content: google nexus broken out of The box, Amazon would not replace or offer support, Tiger Direct would not replace and gooGle would Not replace..  So far my nEXUS HAS BEEN IN THE SHOP FOR REPAIRS 3 TIMES, EACH TIME TAKING ASUS OVER 2 WEEKS FOR REPAIRS.  SO FAR ASUS REPAIR HAS HAD MY TABLET FOR REPAIRS LONGER THAT i HAVE USED IT.  DO NOT BUY FROM AMAZON, TIGER DIRECT OR GOOGLE,  THEY DO NOT BACK THEIR PRODUCTSS,  GARY ACKERSON, WA STATE

Reviews.Title: Nexus 7 talblet camera
Reviews.Author: telaye
Reviews.Content: Google Nexus 7: Taking Pictures & Video With The Front Facing Camera is very challenging although I like the size and everything but was very disappointed to find out that Nexus 7 has a front-facing camera and unfortunately does not come with a default camera icon to take picture facing out. i would like to exchange to the kind I am looking to get with the camera build to take pictures front and out. Thank you

Reviews.Title: Defective
Reviews.Author: Alexnder Cheifot
Reviews.Content: Got defective one - screen starts flickering, jittered and so on.Have to return.Huge disappointment.Will stay with Apple - not an Apple fun, but much better experience over the years...

Reviews.Title: Asus 7 - Great Product!!
Reviews.Author: Robert Dillard
Reviews.Content: Bought this for my wife. The Asus 7 has so much functionality. She takes notes at church and uses many of it's features. Very happy with purchase!!

Reviews.Title: Nexus 7 - The Possibilities are Endless
Reviews.Author: Soben Vun
Reviews.Content: As a starter, I have been a majority-Apple User for quite some time. I've read multiple reviews on the device, and I was quite skeptical on the device. Knowing that my budget was quite tight when buying a tablet, I chose to pursue the Nexus 7. That was one of the best choices I've made on a budget.The reason why I gave the Nexus 7 5 stars is because the device itself is the best for it's worth. For a 32gb device, it offers a versatility of features. I use the device everywhere I go.If you feel confident, you may even choose to pursue Rooting the device to unlock its full capability.The device is easy to use, quick to learn, and it is a keeper for sure.I recommend this product to anyone who seeks a tablet with a budget. The Nexus 7 is definitely the best for its price.

Reviews.Title: Great Item
Reviews.Author: Heath N. Silcox "Blacksheep1977"
Reviews.Content: Wife told me we needed to come into the times and get a tablet. I did some shopping around and read a lot of reviews. So I finally pulled the trigger a few months after she told me to buy one. I would say I am super happy with the Tablet but I have only got to use it once to set it up. My wife has taken it and made it hers. She loves it. From what I have seen it looks like it runs really smooth. The battery out lasts my cellphone and the tablet has more use. She likes that she can get on Facebook, yahoo and ect faster than a computer. Even if its turned all the way off it boots faster than a windows Laptop. It makes it nice when you want to look something up quickly and you want a bigger screen than your Cell Phone.

Reviews.Title: Just an amazing tablet.
Reviews.Author: Victoria Holland
Reviews.Content: I think this is a fast HD tablet , perfect for anywhere. Some people were mad that this tablet doesn't have a micro SD card but with 32 gigs of memory, it truly is not needed! Keep in mind the iPad mini doesn't have one ever either. Just to be clear, a Nexus 7 has a quad core when i pad mini has only a dual core , meaning the Nexus 7 can run more things more efficiently. Also the Nexus 7 has more than twice the ram an iPad mini does so it runs MUCH more faster. ALSO the nexus 7 has much more pixels on the screen than the iPad mini meaning that it has a MUCH better screen resolution. Sorry to get all techy but if you don't believe me search it up.So as you can see, a Nexus 7 is a much better choice than the iPad mini.

Reviews.Title: Cool
Reviews.Author: AlphaHolic "Crystal"
Reviews.Content: Bought this for my Dad. I like it. He likes it. We've had it for around 3 months now. Like it.

Reviews.Title: pretty good for the price
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "Bike rider, book reader, adr...
Reviews.Content: I originally wanted the Samsung tab 2 but the store was out and I wanted one now.  So far I haven't been disappointed in this product.  I was skeptical about only having 32 Gig, but I've added tons of apps and haven't begun to fill it up.  The Jellybean interface is much easier to use than my Samsung Phone with Gingerbread on it.  My wife bought the iPad mini at the same time, and I can't see spending twice plus for a glorified ereader and web browser.  Battery life is pretty good, and the ergonomics are pretty good.  I've had no issues so far with crashing or locking up.

Reviews.Title: Best I have used so far !
Reviews.Author: Joe
Reviews.Content: I've  had it two weeks. I like it. The processor is very fast. Screen is not great, buy very good. Battery life if super. Two or more days without a charge. If Google wants to put another $50 into this tablet, it will be one of the best including Ipad. A great tablet for $200.

Reviews.Title: Is meeting most of my expectations
Reviews.Author: KE
Reviews.Content: Excellent 7 inch tablet, impressed with the Android OS and app store. Some improvements would be an SD slot and a back facing camera

Reviews.Title: My girlfriend is angry
Reviews.Author: filifapion
Reviews.Content: I spend so much time messing with my tablet that my girlfriend has started snarling every time she sees me with it.  I'm not kidding, she snarls.I literally have to pretend I wasn't using it when she walks into the room.  It's worse than my Dad getting on my case about WoW.I love it.  No one can deny my love for it.Seriously, it's amazing; puts up a great fight against the iPad mini

Reviews.Title: Very portable!
Reviews.Author: Isabel M. Villena
Reviews.Content: I bought this to replace my iTouch. I am not at all disappointed. Everything runs beautifully and I like the OS better than Apple's. I wish they had made the bezels smaller on this tablet. The Nexus fits in any type of jean, not shorts, though. If you need an iTouch replacement, this is for you. Portability rocks. Keep in mind it's not an mp3 player but a media consumption device. If you run or do exercise with your device this is not for you though.

Reviews.Title: Nexus 7
Reviews.Author: tony1putt
Reviews.Content: Nexus 7 is the best,nothing better!  screen picture is amazing.  does it all...Why pay for an IPad when you get more for less

Reviews.Title: Best tablet ever
Reviews.Author: Jeff Bell
Reviews.Content: I got this for my girlfriend and she loves it.  If you have an android phone this tablet will not be difficult to use what so ever.

Reviews.Title: Great Tablet for a Great Price.
Reviews.Author: Austin
Reviews.Content: I got this tablet for Christmas and I love it. The screen is amazingly sharp and clear. Way better than the iPad mini. Quad core processor is the most powerful on the market. NVidia Tegra3 is awesome. Great for all ages and needs. only thing that would be better for business is maybe the blackberry playbook. Maybe.

Reviews.Title: Great tablet for the price. The size is great for reading & portability
Reviews.Author: DCG
Reviews.Content: I own an iPad (3rd generation) which I love, but wanted an additional smaller tablet for things like reading. After a lot of research and comparisons to tablets such as the Kindle Fire HD, I went with a Nexus 7.Pros:-The 7" form factor is really good for reading, which is what I primarily got it for. I can hold it comfortably in 1 hand. The faux-leather backing is also comfortable to hold.-Android Jelly Bean is a big improvement over ice cream sandwich.  I had owned an android phone for a couple years in the past before switching to an iPhone, but it's been a year or 2 since I've used it, and they've made some improvements. Ironically, I feel like they improved it by making it even more like iOS. There are some key differences, as Android has widgets, and has different ways of doing some things. While I guess a couple widgets are useful, for the most part, I don't really see the need for them. I tend to just go into apps instead of viewing widgets. Closing open apps is easy, and faster than iOS.-The Google apps that come pre-installed are well designed. I already use many Google services, so setup was easy. Google Now is also well done.-The screen. While the screen is not on par with Apple's retina screen, it is still very nice, and better than most/all of the other non-retina screen tablets currently out there that I've seen.-Google Play. Being able to stream music from Google play is nice to have.-Price. This thing is a realy good tablet for the price.-It's a Nexus/Google tablet, so you'll receive some future OS updates. I don't trust any non-nexus Android devices, as most hardware manufactures just abandon releasing updates for most of their products.Cons:-Lack of apps. I knew this was going to be an issue ahead of time, but it's a bit more an an issue than I expected. First the amount of quality apps available for Android is really not close to the apps available for iOS. A lot of the news apps, guitar/music apps, and toddler apps my daughter uses etc are just not available for Android. Some popular apps seem to just be behind iOS. For example, the Facebook app is pretty much the app that was on iOS about a year ago. The biggest problem is that very few Android apps seem to be optimized for tablets yet. They're mainly phone-apps blown up to fit a larger screen. Being that I mainly got this for reading (and chose it over devices like the Kindle Fire because I do want the additional functionality), I'm not overly concerned with this, but this could be an issue for other people.-Swiping is not as smooth as I'm used to on the iPad. Swiping from side-to-side simply isn't very responsive. I'm not sure whether this is a function of the device, Android, or both. Vertical scrolling seems to lag a bit in some apps, but nothing too bad.-Android Jelly bean is very good, but does not have the same attention to detail as iOS. I've noticed a bunch of small things...such as background images that come with Android not even filling the full screen; I've gotten an 'applauncher' error message a couple times already; and there are some other things they just don't work as well as they should in some cases (ie, moving the curser in Chrome).-Web Browsing. Web browsing can be a bit cumbersome due to the 7" size. Unlike on a phone which loads mobile versions of many sites, and large screen tablets which load fill sites, this loads full desktop sites, but the screen size can make sites it a little tough to navigation without zooming in and out.-The Google Play store. While Google has made some good improvements with Google Play, the Apple App Store is simply much easier to use and find apps.Overall, its a great tablet for the price. I like the 7" size for portability, and for reading for long periods of time. Android is still not as refined as iOS in my opinion, but it's getting there. I don't see this really replacing my iPad in terms of overall use, but it's great for what I wanted it for.

Reviews.Title: Really Good Experience
Reviews.Author: Steven Clark
Reviews.Content: Almost as polished as an iPad. I really like these things for what they are...But my nieces absolutely love them. I got them one each for Xmas and they haven't put them down since.

Reviews.Title: A slick little tablet
Reviews.Author: My thoughts
Reviews.Content: I'm a novice tablet user and I love this tablet. It is incredibly fast, easy to use, easy to hold, and the 1280x800 resolution is sharp and easy on the eyes. It has great voice detection typing, google maps connects to the tablet's GPS and identifies my location, it supports skype, you can touch another device to exchange info, the gorilla glass screen resists scratches, and it connects to my wifi instantly. The 1.2m camera could be better - it does read QR codes but can't scan barcodes. I added the Firefox browser and Firefox Beta enabling me to download Adobe Flash, and then live stream videos.

Reviews.Title: No SIM Card, Good Customer Support
Reviews.Author: Bill Baehr "whipperin1"
Reviews.Content: 03/07: I got my Nexus 7 yesterday from Google and it did not come with the Sim card. There was an envelope for the card but it was empty and the card was not installed in the device either. I called Google Support and they instructed me to send the Nexus 7 back and get a replacement Nexus 7 in order for Google to send me a Sim card. Seems pretty wasteful on Google's end. Google also charges my credit card for the replacement device until Google receives my defective device. Couldn't they just mail me a Sim card?The Google Support call was good. I talked to an English speaking person that sounded like she was from the USA. I really dislike trying to have a support conversation with someone from Mexico or India or any other foreign land. I was not put on hold either which is amazing!I also had a problem with the Nexus 7 not connecting with my Wifi at first. It did eventually connect. Once connected the Nexus 7 performed very well. It looks well made. The voice search feature was fun and it made very few mistakes recognizing words.  I will add to the is review as time goes on and hopefully be able to end up giving the Nexus 7 four or five stars.03/08: I received a replacement Nexus 7 device today and guess what? No Sim card was included. Please see my video. I called Google Support and they did promised that I would receive an email from a Support Specialist within 24-48 hours about getting me a Sim card. Why can't Google just mail me a SIMS card?03/11/13 On Friday afternoon, I stopped by the Woodland, California, AT&T; store to see if they would give me a SIMS card to use in my Nexus 7. They had one but they wanted a $36 activation fee. I declined. When I called Google support on Friday, I was promised an email from Google Support Specialist within 24-48 hours to resolve this matter. It has been over 72 hours and I still have not received and email from Google Support.  I am looking forward to Google resolving this issue.03/12/13 Called Google Support today to find out what is up with the Sim card since I did not get the promised email from them. Google Support suggested that I go to a local AT&T; store for a Sim card and they said I was supposed to get an email to do that on March 10. I did not get the email. I explained that I already went to an AT&T; store and AT&T; wanted an activation fee of $36 for the card. Google said that the activation fee must be paid even if I got the card from Google. I told Google that the sales person at the AT&T; store said that I would not have to pay the activation fee if I got the Sim card from Google. Google Support said that all they can do is to send me another Nexus 7 with the Sim card. So, here we go again with another replacement process.03/12/13: Email exchange between Google Support and me: I called AT&T; and they will not set up a prepaid account without the Sim card that should have been provided with my Nexus 7. In order to set up a prepaid account I would need to have the Sim card that I paid for from Google. AT&T; suggested that I return the Nexus 7 for a refund because I am not being taken care of properly by Google in this matter and buy a tablet through AT&T.;I have been back and forth all day with Google Support. They finally figured out that I have to return the Nexus 7 for a refund and then wait up to 14 days after receipt for a credit to my account and then I can order another Nexus 7 with an AT&T; Sims card. What a mess! I love the product, so I will order a Nexus 7 without a Sims card instead. The Sims card feature is not work all this trouble for me.

Reviews.Title: Badly named and priced at Amazon
Reviews.Author: Charles Heath
Reviews.Content: None of the websites I looked at sold this product for more than $249 (Dec 15, 2012) and none of them mis-named it with the name ASUS (which might be different tablet typically) that confuses the issue. ASUS makes their own tablets and also makes them for others who place their own brand/name on them. This is the Google tablet marketed by Google, not ASUS. Again, overpriced at Amazon and badly marketed due to misnaming. However, given a choice of this product with the latest and greatest Android OS and the only one that will get Android updates in a timely fashion and anything else, my inclination is this one. This one is also not tied to only one marketplace so a wider variety of apps and apps written for the latest OS are available that may not be available for any of the Amazon Fire products.  I usually buy most stuff on Amazon but this time, a quick trip to a local office, big box, or electronics store is the same or cheaper including taxes.

Reviews.Title: Worst Customer Service, EVER
Reviews.Author: SHIGEHITO ONDA
Reviews.Content: So, after a good start on this product, it stopped charging and stopped turning on at all.  After a couple of months of not using it, we finally decided to send it back for a warranty repair.  That was Jan 20.  Today is March 20, and it's still not fixed.First, the call center guy made me ship it to Canada (was supposed to go to TX).  Once they received it in Canada, they sent it to Texas, I think that was Feb 5 or so.  Since then no one has contacted me.  I've only been in contact with them, and they don't know the status of it at all.  All it says is that it is in "repair."  No one there can find out what's going on.  A supervisor once told me that they'll have a solution figured out by the end of last week, but now it's the end of next week and nothing is resolved.  If I'd known how bad ASUS's customer service was, I would not have bought this product.I would never buy another ASUS product again, EVER!

Reviews.Title: Just don't bother. I returned it twice to manufacturer for repair
Reviews.Author: ipbabble
Reviews.Content: If I knew then what I know now I wouldn't have bothered buying this product. I have several Apple products but I wanted to try out an Android based tablet device. I like open source. What a waste of money and time with this Asus device.I've had to return this product to Asus twice at my own expense when it stopped working.  This last time it was returned to me fixed with no explanation. I asked for one and was told that I need to charge it regularly - i.e. don't stop using this for a few days or it might not recharge or work. I was also told not to over charge - i.e. don't leave it plugged in after it is fully charged. So basically I have to charge it just right. This means I can't leave it plugged in over night and I can't leave it uncharged for a "long" period of time. (Where "long" means a couple of days or more.)When it is working it's not bad - though the screen touch calibration isn't great. But it might stop working and you have to send it back to be repaired.Next time mine stops working I might just throw it out. What's the point?  I'm disappointed because I had high hopes. I wanted a working Android tablet. I can't trust this one - which means it probably will discharge when I forget to charge it and then it's trash. :-(

Reviews.Title: Piece of Junk!
Reviews.Author: shanda
Reviews.Content: I bought the nexus 7 after reading some glowing reviews. The first tablet I had to return to the store because the internet did not work, right out the box. The second tablet did not rear it's ugly head till a month later, right after the return warranty for the store...getting hung up intermittently, then being hung up to the point it would not shut off. I called tech support, their answer to everything is to wipe the system clean, which it would not, so I had to send it in. 6 weeks later they send it back saying it was the battery. The same thing happened a month later and had to go thru the whole process again. This time they said it was the mother board, but I asked them for a replacement as I noticed the side of the tablet was a little loose. They would only give a refurbished product, not new. So essentially I just paid all this money for a used product. I just received someone else's tablet that did not work. When received it back, 6 weeks later, the unit would not hold a charge. Another call to tech support they said to wipe it clean again! Oh gee, I would have to send it back again! I could not believe it! In the time I have had this unit, 10 months, it has never worked properly, I have been without it most of the time, the company has known issues with this tablet and refuse to give you a brand new product or even compensate you at all for all the inconvenience and heartache this $250.00 piece of junk has given me. The products warranty now expires in a couple months and I have yet to be able to enjoy it. I did buy the extended warranty at the store, but you have to go thru ASUS first, and really, recycling a piece of junk over and over is going to give you what you had in the first place. Do yourself a favor and get another brand, as they do not stand behind their product.

Reviews.Title: second review
Reviews.Author: Susan Rose
Reviews.Content: This is the second review of this product. My first review was pretty happy and hopeful.This one well, I think there should be a lemon law for this tablet.  I do not think I should haveto have to hold down my sound ( increase  ) side of the button along with my on button for one minuteto turn on the device.  If the battery runs down, that is what you need to do.  Why?I think Asus should let everyone who has to do this return the tablet for a recalland give them one that works.  No wonder so many people return it. What a disappointmentto the guy who gave his kid one for Christmas.

Reviews.Title: Very pleased
Reviews.Author: Ryan Wood
Reviews.Content: I am an Android OS fan and was skeptical on getting the tablets because they have always had less popular reviews compared to teh IPAD. Well I am extremely happy with my Nexus 7 the only issue I have come across with it is it didnt have a Camera app easily downloaded one and it works perfect videos are smooth and clear. The ease of download is great even with the really extra ridiculously slow wifi servers in Afghanistan while I was deployed. cheaper than the IPAD with faster speeds than the MINI I sat side by side with a friend of mine who has the New IPAD MINI and the Nexus was faster in all categories except for soudness of the external speakers. I would strongly recommend this Tablet from someone who also owns an IPAD teh 3rd Generation I like my Android more now.

Reviews.Title: Awesome until it breaks, twice.
Reviews.Author: A. Link
Reviews.Content: I love this tablet. The screen is great, it doesn't feel laggy, it feels great in the hands, the size is perfect. Unfortunately since I purchased one from Gamestop in September of 2012 I have ended up with two dead Nexuses. When my first one broke in December (screen was still backlit but no display) Gamestop let me exchange it and pay the difference for the larger 32 GB tablet. Last week that tablet broke (display died, random patterns on the screen). Yes I can send it in to Asus for a refurbished one but is that really worth it? I wish I could just have my money back as I assume I will just end up with another dead tablet in a few months.UPDATE: Shortly after leaving this review an ASUS representative replied to my review and gave me contact information to escalate my RMA. I had forwarded the email notification of that reply to their contact but they never received it. When I emailed that contact directly they did respond the next day. I shipped my tablet out on June 15th and had it repaired and back to me on July 2nd. The tablet was repaired and the screen works now. I will update this review if it breaks again. I updated the rating from "I hate it" to "I don't like it". If this tablet lasts more than a few months I'm sure it would warrant an "It's OK" rating. Perhaps for the next run of Nexus tablets they won't have so many quality control issues.

Reviews.Title: Easy to use
Reviews.Author: Jason L. Baker
Reviews.Content: I bought this for my 11 yr old son.  He loves it!  It is easy enough for even my 5 yr old to play around with too.  It is a nice tablet.

Reviews.Title: WOW....glad I finally broke the strings from Apple. This thing is AMAZING!
Reviews.Author: Keith in NYC
Reviews.Content: I've had the Nexus 7 32GB for about a month now, and not a day goes by where I don't learn something new and amazing, and thank G-D I'm free from the nonsense Apple made me go through with their products. Don't get me wrong, I used to be a big fan of Apple's nano, their touch, and the iPad, but I've just gotten so disgusted over the years with Apple for the following reasons:1. being forced to sync/dock to iTunes (only to have my entire music library accidentally deleted more than once)2. having to go through gymnastics and gerry-rig other third party apps to try and place my iTunes library on more than one computer or more than one Apple product (all which I own, mind you), and STILL not having something sync up (either music, or pictures, or movies or books etc.)3. having to pay a HUGE premium to get a little extra memory (which cannot be expanded).4. Let's not forget the dopey non-replaceable battery.5Let's move on to the Nexus and I'll explain why this is so fantastic.  First thing, EVERYTHING is sync'd effortlessly over WiFI.  Updates to their operating system, all their apps...EVERYTHING. No more having to sync with a computer app (iTunes).  And when you're tired of an app, you just un-install it right on the device (seems quite obvious to me, but not to Apple. they make you go through iTunes again). And trust me, there are thousands of fantastic and free apps...for music, games, magazines, productivity, calendars, phoe calls over wifi, twitter, facebook EVERYTHING!!!!And guess what, nearly limitless storage on the Nexus. Yes, it has a fixed internal memory and no card slot, but just buy a $2.99 app (called Media to Go) and buy a $2.00 usb to usb micro connector cord and you can store movies, books, music everything on a little SD card. Simply connect the card to the Nexus and you're good to go. You can save all the precious on-board memory in the tablet for processing. And this same set up let's you connect a mouse, a keyboard, nearly anything. And it works flawlessy on the Nexus. No drivers, or special connectors needed (unlike Apple which constantly changes their docking connections, ports, chargers etc.).And the speed of this thing is LIGHTNING fast....quicker than my 2g ipad.  (oh, and although it's not advertised, the battery on the tablet IS replaceable. Just snap off the back cover and snap in a battery).The look and feel of this device is amazing. Magazines, pictures, games (Temple Run 2 anyone???) looks and works flawlessly.  Nearly every day, someone on the subway asks me how I like the device and that they're going to get one as well.  The screen is great, and the back cover has sort of a rubbery coating that makes holding this thing a pleasure (and no more smudges).Guys, if you've been holding off for a tablet, please try this out yourself or talk to someone who owns one.  I am so happy I purchased this (as opposed to the iPad mini which I looked at for quite awhile).  The Nexus 7 is more value for your money, expandable and in my humble opinion, a superior product.

Reviews.Title: Nexus 7 review
Reviews.Author: Jim Fiddelke
Reviews.Content: Pros:Price!Google Play market is great. Not as many choices as the Apple Store, but it's getting there.Build quality is outstanding. Love the rubberized, grippy back.Books look great on the 7 inch screen, and the G.P market has plenty of them.It's good to know you'll always be first in line for updates.The smaller 7 inch screen size is very good for smaller hands, and also for playing games that use the gyroscope, like Riptide GP.The processor is blazing fast! No frame rate issues at all with Tegra 3 games like Dead Trigger or Riptide GP. Project Butter also makes the user interface zippy and responsive.Chrome is standard.Ehh:Decent screen resolution. Pixels are barely visible, only if you look very closely.Screen isn't very bright.No storage expansion, so go for the 32gb model. That should be enough for the average joe.Charging isn't very quick.No rear camera. Not that I would take pictures with it anyway.Cons:My unit (bought from hhgregg) had a busted speaker.Screen size. In the days where most new smartphones are upwards of 4 inches diagonal, a 7 inch tablet just doesn't seem like a good investment.Screen is too small for web browsing, in my opinion.The large bezels on the top/bottom and small bezels on the sides make the tablet feel unnecessarily narrow.Conclusion:Unfortunately, because of the speaker issue, small screen area, and an issue with booting up the device, I had to return my Nexus 7 just 2 weeks after I got it for Christmas. However, Asus makes great products and I just ordered my Transformer Infinity. This tablet will be great for younger kids who just want to watch movies, read books, and play games, but for someone like me that will use it for email, web browsing, and taking notes, I would recommend going for a 10 inch screen tablet (Nexus 10 or Transformer Infinity are my two non-iPad recommendations).

Reviews.Title: Nexux 7 was a gift to replace a very slow Acer w/ Windows 7
Reviews.Author: J. Mershon
Reviews.Content: I don't know about others but, it seems that any notebook or netbook produced before 2011 is painfully slow. I've finally given up on Windows 7 and PC's because of this. It's just not right that a 2 year old PC is no longer able to keep up even after thoroughly cleaning the system of all spyware and other programs that slow consume memory making it frustrating to do simple tasks like browse and search the web, do email and download some music and videos on occasion.The Nexus 7 was the perfect solution for a device that can be used anywhere in the house or where there is access to WIFI. It is fast and because it is based on the Android operating system, there are countless applications for it.
